Bottle; pours a cloudy caramel color with a khaki head; sweet aroma of caramel, dark fruits, chocolate, wood, and booze; taste is sweet with caramel, dark fruits, and toffee with notes of chocolate, wood, honey, and coconut; dry, boozy finish

Pours barely translucent chocolate with a thin pale buff head. Aroma offers chocolate, roast malt and caramel tones. Flavor echoes the aroma with stronger notes. Mouthfeel features firm body and peppy fizz. Sucaba one down.

(Tap sample @ CBC 2016 Green Session, Copenhagen) Pours hazy deep amber with a dark cream head. Aroma is sweet, fruity and barrel heavy overall, lots of layers of caramel, toffee, vanilla, toast, bourbon, dried fruits, figs, oak. Flavours follow the nose a lot, rich, almost fudgey toffee, caramel, brown sugar, toasted notes, slight chocolate, bourbon, lots of vanilla from the oak, dried and candied figs, berries and dates, tobacco, new oak. A touch of booze and drying from the oak counteract the sweetness in the finish, but it¬ís still a rich, sweet beer with a full mouthfeel and soft carbonation. Very nice to sip slowly, if perhaps not the best choice at a festival.

Bottle, 2016 vintage, picked up at Smokes n Suds. Brown pour with a short lived beige head. Aroma is delightfully sweet; great barrel notes along with vanilla, caramel, and toffee. Bottle tasting at DobryZbeer

Strong Dark Cherry notes, with a sweet bite that balances out the high alcohol notes. Some vanilla and toffi taste. Very unique and full flavored Barley Wine.

At the Barleywine event. Aroma is bourbon, barrel, hops, caramel, toffee. Appearance is amber brush, light tan head, clear. Taste is caramel, hops, bourbon, barrel, toffee, dark fruit. Mouthfeel is medium to heavy body, light carbonation, caramel bourbon aftertaste. Overall, it¬ís been a very long time coming. I¬ím happy to finally try this.

UPDATED: JAN 26, 2017 650ml bottle at home. Reddish brown colour, foamy beige head. Really nice nose with sweet malty dried fruits, toffee, coconut, candied apple, vanilla, bourbon blending in nicely. Taste is a bit off balance in booze and dry/bitterness (leather, hoppy), maybe English style but has great malty complexity and bourbon notes. Aftertaste lingers but not really long. High carbonation, good body, lacks an oily/thick mouthfeel.

Dark reddish brown pour from 22o bottle at home. A tiny ring of white head. Carmel, oak, candy, butterscotch and smooth. Doesn¬ít have a bite at all for the high ABV. Delicious. One of the best BW I¬íve had

UPDATED: DEC 28, 2016 Aroma: Wow. Bourbon Barrel, coconut, vanilla, caramel, & slight roasted nuts. Taste: big bourbon, coffee, toffee, caramel. Overall: Beautiful beer, ABV concealed so well to showcase the Barrel and base beer. Excellent.

Sample at CBC Green Session 2016. Dark amber with white head. Big, boozy caramel aroma and taste with vanilla, oak, coconut, dried figs and dark fruits. Long, boozy finish. Nice, but not overwhelming.

On tap at Firkin Tavern. Aroma of wood, old houses. A mellow barleywine with usual dark stone fruit notes. The bourbon barrel is probably nicely balanced for most people. I like barrel-aged beers to be like getting hit over the head with a barrel. Could be more viscous.

Tap at the Growler Spot in Fulshear. Dark hazy brown with amber highlights and pretty much no head. Aroma of caramel, nuts, gingerbread, and praline. Taste is sweet, moderately boozy and lightly bitter. Full bodied with low carbonation.

2013 bottle, courtesy of Will (wchesser) -- cheers! Huge is the only word to describe this. Huge bourbon aroma. Huge flavor from the high abv, the residual sugars, and especially all of that oak. Throw in the huge ABV, and you¬íve got one beast of a beer here. Lots of barleywine flavor -- raisins, sugar, molasses -- but the dominating taste was oak from the barrel. Great stuff.

22oz bottle pours out a rich amber topped with a small tan head. Nose is big bourbon barrel notes vanilla brown sugar pit fruit sweetness toffee caramel spice. Taste is more of the heavy sweet malts plenty of candy notes big bourbon barrel vanilla and plenty of booze.
Bottle. Pours a copperish color. Aroma and taste are caramel, bourbon, chocolate, and dark fruits.

2011 vintage 22oz bottle labeled as Abacus. Pours a very hazy, deep reddish brown color with a very small beige head that settles quickly and rejoins the body below. The aroma is really nice showing notes of dark fruits, sweet toffee, toasted caramel, a hint of chocolate, bourbon, and soft oak laden vanilla. Very smooth with very little heat. The flavor follows with the sweet toffee and toasted caramel malts up front followed by notes of dark fruits, dark chocolate, bourbon, soft oak, and toasted vanilla from the wood. Really complex flavors and very smooth with very little heat. Nearly full bodied and slick on the palate with subtle carbonation that leads to a lengthy and sweet bourbon caramel finish. Delicious stuff as this bottle has held up beautifully. Firestone Walker never seems to disappoint with their barrel aged offering. Awesome beer.

(Firestone Walker Sucaba) Bottle, 650 ml. Served into a snifter at home, ABV 12.5%
Dark mahoganny brown colour on the body, almost a finger of dark tan head on top, with average retention.
Aroma of caramel, toffee, dark fruits, alcohol, dried figs, raisins, dates, vanilla, ligth leather.
Taste has bourbon, vanilla, pretty sweet, some fudge and chocolate notes, plums dark fruits, caramel, toffee,alcohol, light wood, sugars.
Medium thick body, soft carbonation.
I will probably have a headache tomorrow if I don¬ít stop drinking this now but I just can¬ít, great beer.

CBC 2016 Green session. Dark brown body with a small tanned head. Aroma of dark fruit, nuts, cognac and chocolate. Taste of mocha, strawberry, chocolate and oak. Thick body, beautifully balanced palate, with a sweet malty backbone. An excellent barley wine!
Very good balance, the spirit of a scotch with the body of an ale. Very enjoyable.

Aromas of toffee, caramel, cocoa. Hazy bronze with a mostly lasting off-white head. Sweet, boozy, caramel, red fruit. Full bodied.
Tap @CBC16. Clear copper, small beige head. Dried fruit and malt aroma, wood. Flavour has sweet malt, frit and wood. Bitter and smooth. Very sippable.

2012 vintage. Dark brown pour, baby finger of fast disipating head. Aroma or marshmallow, whisky. Light alcohol warming, marshmallow, bourbon, vanilla, raisin. Medium body and lower carbonation.

Bottle brought to Prague by Benh and shared with Wolfcarnival. Cheers pals. beer of the night in my opinion and it was keeping some pretty outrageous company. It was so complex and rich. A real heavywight beer. The sheer balance of wood, bourbon, caramel and booze was heavenly. It spells like Shakespeare if Shakespeare was a damn cowboy.

22oz bottle 2013 vintage pours dark reddish brown with light edges and a small head. Lots of rich sweet dark fruit, malty cherry, cocoa, spice, toast, vanilla, caramel, syrup. Big, rich, sweet, complex, creamy. Very delicious.
On tap at Mackeys Hideout. Reddish brown pour, no head to speak of. Aroma is big time bourbon. Flavor is sweet, dark fruit and slightly bready. Big warm, boozy finish. I like it!

UPDATED: JUL 12, 2016 Draft pour at Brouwers, left over from Hard Liver. Pours a reddish brown with a lasting fizz head. Aroma is viciously sweet with vanilla notes. Flavor is bready, raisin up front, with a huge dominant play dough addition and heavy linger. Kind of a weird beer for me. High expectations met with an odd, cringing play dough flavor. I¬íll be the odd guy out and say I had a rough time with this. Will retry soon.
RERATE: as promised.  2011 Abacus bottle, shared by Tcon.  Huge thanks!  Dark brown pour with no head left.  Mellowed aroma of vanilla and raisin.  Less sweet than noted before. Full body, intense flavor, very hot mouthfeel, lingering flavor. 
Sweet, moderate bitterness. 
Barley drops malt flavor.

On tap. 2013 vintage. Pours a dark brown with light head. Aromas of sticky brown sugar, sweet malts and caramel. Flavors of drambuie, grass, brown sugar, light wood and alcohol without the heat. Ready to drink. Really nice.

On tap 2010 Abacus. Pours a dark brown with light head. Aromas of dak sugar/caramel and sweetened liquorice. Flavors of cane sugar, brown sugar, sweet bready malts and dry sweet chocolate. Still sweet and hot but tasty. 8/4/8/3/16

2014 draft on tap at 2SP Barleywine Event..pours a crimson red color..however hard to tell with bad light..nose is complex with vanilla, oak, toffee as billed, not getting any chocolate though..smokey bourbon mash really comes through with a deeper whiff..taste is really layered which is what I appreciate in offerings such as this..malty toffee, sweetness and bourbon heat shine through on the mouthfeel..the high abv is well hidden at first but then bam that bourbon heat and warmth provides a punch at the end..don¬ít really enjoy barleywines that much but after having this all other barleywines don¬ít reallly compare to the bourbon goodness present here..not much in terms of head or carbonation but to be expected from the style..quite enjoyable

Bottle - loads of vanilla and oak aromas . Toffee , vanilla , oak and dried fruits are the dominate flavors . Excellent ale ! 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Draft at Holsteins in Las Vegas. Pretty good, but did not "wow" me. Almost no head and strong boozy overtones. Barley wine was pretty good, but barrel aging overpowered the underlying flavor.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
2015 bottle. Pours ruby colored with no head. Nose is dark fruit, coconut, bourbon. Taste adds caramel and toffee. Boozy.

Bottle shared from Blackrock cellar. Pours strong tea brown. Butterscotch, wethers original, oak, wood, toffee, molasses, sugar, whiskey and tea. Flavour is butterscotch, rum, tannin, grainy brown sugar. Smooth mouthfeel, liquid sugar. Abv is managed well. Oh to have more.

UPDATED: FEB 10, 2016 2015 vintage, 13.3% ABV.
Very dark ruby-brown pour with a modest head that gives way to a thin tan head. Smells of bourbon, caramel and a bit of barrel sourness., followed by more delicate notes of chocolate, raisins and cocoa, and some macerated cherries too - very complex smell. The taste is dominated by bourbon and caramel and well balanced by hop bitterness. The alcohol is quite present in the taste, but in a pleasant way. Hot aftertaste due to the alcohol. Soft mouthfeel, medium body. It would have been a bit better if it were thicker.

Bottle shared at pre-CBC 2015 tasting by Valgreen. Rated from memory... lol. Pours dark reddish brown with a medium offwhite head. Aroma has lots of vanilla, dark dried fruits, lots of dates, raisins, bourbon, caramel, fudge. Taste is fruity, bourbon, vanilla, malty, caramel, chocolate.

Tasted from bottle. Pours a dark beige with khaki head. Aroma is full of dark fruit, caramel, licorice, a little nutty. Taste...this beer is big! Very complex. So much going on it hard to describe. Moderate to heavily sweet. Flavors of raisin, plums, vanilla, chocolate, caramel, toffee, biscuits, maple syrup, bourbon. Overall an incredible barley wine. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Finally getting around to this, seems fitting. Bottle, deep brown beer skiff of almond colored foam, decent lace. Aroma raisin, vanilla, sweet cherries, cookies, milk chocolate, almonds, licorice. Taste is vanilla cream, yeah, ice cream, and bourbon, cookies, anise, oak, almonds, pretty sweet, but big vanilla, balanced by that almond and dark fruit and a hint of roastyness, Palate is rich and thick, carb subdued. This is not my style, but wow, this really is amazing! Pairing this with a cured goat cheese...just stop it! Really, how can I raise my rating?! But I must! Wow!

Pours deep red with a slight light-brown head which soon recedes. Aroma is caramel, toffee, oak, vanilla and slight bourbon. Taste is sweet caramel, toffee, malts, slight bitter cocoa, sweet coconut and some moderately tart red berry. Full bodied.

2015 edition, thanks to Maek at Osaka bottle share. 
L: poured a murky off-brown with a small head. 
S: a big bourbon whisky nose, supported by deep rich malt and a touch of sweetness. 
T: again, very alcoholic, lots of whisky flavouring, a well-balanced sipper with some dark fruit and coming through. 
F: great mouthfeel, heavy and warming yet smooth over the palate. 
O: it was great to try this, pushing the style into more liqueur territory.

Firestone Walker Sucaba - bottle shared by Maek - thanks for helping me finally try this. It pours a deep reddish gold pour with a supremely malty caramel. Thebody is med-full while the flavor is oaky caramel and bready malts. This is delicious. Caramel and malts all the way.

2014 edition. Poured into a chalice on 09.22.15. A: Bourbon, oak, brown sugar, and cherry. A: Thin off white foam recedes to a ring. Hazy deep dark red body. T: Oak, bourbon, vanilla, brown sugar, caramel, and cherry cough syrup dominate. Raisin and toasted coconut are subtle. All flavors are blended nicely. P: Somewhat oily with an astringent finish. O: There is a load of alcohol heat despite its age. If there was any hop profile, it¬ís gone now. This is a great entry point for someone who doesn¬ít like hoppy American style barleywines.

Bottle at THT. Dark brown with small off white head. Sweet grains and malts, some light chocolate, lots of cognac, boozy, quite spicy. Very sweet and light boozy bitter finish. Full bodied. Very alcoholic but nice.

Sample at September THT.
thin white head. Hazy amber pour. A very good barley wine.
Bottle Clear dark brown, little head. Aroma sweet. Taste, carmel, sticky, sweet, slight bitterness. Was expecting more from this disappointed
Bottle shared with friends during poker. Lots of heavy dark fruit and chocolate. Barrel wood flavors too. I liked this a lot.

bomber to snifter poured a medium brown with smallish head. the aroma took me a minute or so to figure out and once I did I was in love with this beer. what transpired was the blend of chocolate and coconut mixed with the sweet malts that make a barley wine. the flavor was much more intense of the chocolate front and back and the mix of the coconut finishes with a soft warm boozy feeling. definite sipper in front of the fireplace.

Very balanced and extremely drinkable for a barleywine. Alcohol is present only in the aftertaste giving a warming sensation as it goes down. The barrel is very present, along with a lot of caramel and even some hops on the finish. Syrupy body, very easy to drink.

UPDATED: SEP 11, 2015 Renowned American barley wine, with creamy, moussy, light greyish beige head, breaking in instants; colour hazy copper with ruby hue. Powerful and enchanting bouquet of sweet cherries soaked in brown rhum, ruby port, white pepper, vanilla, Hennessy cognac, candied figs, Belgian chocolates, candied orange, strawberry, oaky tannins, hints of mocha ice cream, caramel, almond, roasted coconut. Intense taste profile beginning with lots of candied, but not sticky sweetness, raisins, candied cherries, hint of orange, softly tingling carbo with velvety, vinous mouthfeel, noble sourish touch, smooth caramelly, slightly nutty with a lovely milk chocolate touch to it, while the initial candied sweetness lingers on; finish is a reprisal of all this, but with drying oaky woodiness added, a dash of citrussy hop bitterishness and of course a deep warmth of brandy- and bourbon-like alcohol, perhaps very slightly burning on the root of the tongue, but not disturbing at all; wonderful bittersweet, warming barley wine, not as hoppy as many other Americans in the style and therefore better suited in the English barley wine style, which, from what I read, is indeed the intention. Wonderful and exemplary for the style.
Drank at ZeeBra 2015 (20-6-2015). This was a dissapointment for me. Very overwhelming bitterness, with very present whiskey dominated by the intense alcohol one-dimensionality.

Decent brew from firestone, with a lot of different tastes that gets trough. Some wood, vanilla and chocolate, but also something pleasant that I can¬ít really name, but seems very familiar. Nice one.
Oak, bourbon, chocolate, vanilla somewhat sweet aftertaste. Warm alcohol finish.

Bottle of the 2013. Shared by my buddy. All I can say about this beer is wow. Barley wines are hit or miss for me. I usually stray away from sweeter beers. I don¬ít much care for many English-leaning beers. Sucaba is all of those things, yet so damn delicious. The beer is thick and ruby in appearance with a huge head. Time has cleared out the body. The massive aroma is sweet, but tastefully so and endlessly complex. There are notes of vanilla, oak, sherry, earth, dark fruits, raisins, toasted brown sugar and bread. The palate is huge and boozy in a very good way, not the way the burns, but rather nicely warms me up and commands slow-sipping enjoyment. All these sweet flavors don¬ít come across as sticky or sugary they just delightfully intermingle. All the character is harmonious and balanced with a tasteful oaken, sherry note. The flavor is much like the aroma but really brings out the notes of standing in a humidor. Ladies and gentlemen, this is how you do a classic barleywine. Phenomenal.

 Poured from bottle (2013) into a snifter

 Appearance ¬ñ The beer pours a super deep copper color with thick tow finger of tan colored head. The head has a good level of retention, slowly fading to leave a light level of foamy lace on the sides of the glass.

 Smell ¬ñ The aroma of the beer is quite a caramel and toffee smell mixed with a ton of fruit aromas ranging from darker stone fruits to lighter fruits. Apple, cherry, raisin, are the strongest with hints of other fruits within. A good deal of oak and lot of bourbon booziness are there as well creating a very warming smell overall.

 Taste ¬ñ The taste begins big caramel and butterscotch flavor. A big bready and doughy flavor is there as well. A bourdon and vanilla flavor begin working their way onto the tongue along with the caramel and toffee transitions to a molasses and brown sugar flavor. A ton of oaky bourbon booziness hits the tongue toward the middle to the end of the taste with some dark fruit flavors starting to be sensed as well. The booziness gets a bit hot at the very end and is combine with a bit of a herbal and earthy hop flavor to leave a very warming and sweet flavor on the tongue.

 Mouthfeel ¬ñ The body of the beer is on the thicker and creamier side with a carbonation level that is on the lower side. Both are quite appropriate for the style and match the huge sweet and boozy of the flavors rather well, making for a rather slow sipper. 

 Overall ¬ñ A bit on the boozy and oaky side with a ton of sweetness. A rather robust Barley wine. Not one I would likely frequent frequently, but a nice on to try none the less.

Bottle shared by some nice folks. Pours a cola brown with tan head. Aroma is nice, some vanilla, oak, coffee, with some caramel. Taste was delicious, flavors of coffee, caramel, vanilla, and booze all intermingling together nicely.

UPDATED: JUL 7, 2016 Double whammy! This followed the FW Stickee Monkee. Alcohol burn apparent, but not overpowering. Pure barley essence, aroma and taste. A real gem.2014, 2015 & 2016 versions rated.

Chocolate, coffee, alcohol, smoke, woody, earthy, resin found a beer to be very strong but palatable who love the aroma the chocolate notes that I took him to the upon or very divine but the flavor of the nuttiness due to the tobacco within the product give it I¬ím more of an alcohol tone to it so was I in your mouth the feel of it was sort of like whiskey after all it is

Tap @ Mikkeller & Friends, Copenhagen 15/7-14. Sweet and caramelish, coconut and Bounty-chocolate, chocolate with vanilla notes, some light alcoholic notes. The finish is long, dry with notes of coconuts. A really nice one.

Bottle share at Tribes Alehouse. Pour is very dark brown with a very small white head. Aroma of roasted malts, oak, and bourbon, but it is faint. Flavor is chocoalte, vanilla, coconut, tobacco, caramel, and booze. Finish is hot.

Sampled at ESBLS. It poured a dark amber brown color with a off-white head. The aroma was of bourbon, cherry, vanilla, oak, coconut and roasted malts. The taste was of vanilla, oak, coconut, cherry, plum, chocolate and roasted malts. Just awesome.

2011 bottling - Pours bronze with a reddish hue and a small beige head. The aroma has toffee, oak, English earthiness, sweet maltiness, candy aspects, caramel, dark fruits, alcohol, chocolate and some vanilla. It has a full thick rich body with a bit of a bit and only a little bit of semi-sharp carbonation remaining. The flavor begins with caramel, lots of charred wood/oak, vanilla, raisins, dates, alcohol, coconut,  toasted malt and earthy British yeastiness. The finish has some toffee, bread and sweet malt added to the mix. Coconut aspect increases as it warms. Very nice barleywine.

Bottle to snifter. Pours a deep brown with a red tint. Minimal head that faded quickly. Aroma of bourbon, oak, dark chocolate, dark cherries, and some vanilla. Taste was a little sweet, but not in a bad way. Reminded me of chocolate covered cherries dipped in a nice bourbon. This is a sipper and you can feel the 13% creep up on you. Very tasty.
@ Mikkeller and Friends. Hel del choklad och en del kokos. Lite vanilj och kokos i smaken.
Bottle at Craig¬ís. Pours dark brown, lots of sweet toffee and vanilla, fruity berries.

Fra fad p√• Mikkellerfriends, Stefansgade juli-14: hold p√• hatte, her stiger en intens aroma av svisker, m√∏rk sjokolade, like m√∏rke kriseb√¶r, kokos og vanilje. Like intens smak, hver minste munnfull nytes til det ytterste. Eksepsjonelt rund og fristende, fristende. Mersmak i h√∏yeste potens. Her gjelder det √• mobilisere viljestyrken hvis man skal komme seg uskadet hjem gjennom parken. Minneverdig.

Deep brown color with almost no head. Aroma is roasted malt, some hops, caramel, brown sugar, breadines and a lot of alcohol. Taste is sweet roasted malt with alcohol present big time. A beer a didn't enjoy cause I don't like beers with a smell or taste of alcohol really present.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

This Barleywine barrel aged is very good. If you go at Russian River brewing, you can to buy This Beer 2 years ago. The older better! 
Much wood, oak and toffee.

Bottle shared on the London Bimble 26/04/2014. Huge thanks to Bruce for this rare treat. Aroma is complex, vanilla, caramel, sweet praline. ice caramel brown coloured pour with a small light tan head. Flavour is salted caramel, toffee, praline, burnt sugars and oak. Palate is viscous, sweet treacle and very smooth on the tongue. Lingering oak and complx sugars. Very very tasty complex beer.
out of bottle. pours brown slight head . nose is bourbon but also sweet dark fruit. taste is the same with dark chocolate and some barrel. excellent.
Draught at Oskar Blues. Dark brown color, beige head. Bitter taste with hops, toffee, caramel, ripe fruits, pine and raisins. Bitter finish with hops, raisin and pine. Excellent barley wine.

Bottle thatnks to Motherbrother. Pours dark dark reddish brown with a fairly dense off white head. Aroma is packed with vanilla, overripe, dried fruits, port wine, bourbon barrel, coconut. Holy S***, this smells good! Taste is very fruity, and very bourbon-ish. Again this port wine, oak, gentle roast, coconut, slight chocolate. medium high carbonation. Just my style of barley wine!

2013 bomber bottle. Aroma is bourbon with some barley wine in it. Appearance is brown with a little cream color head. Taste has bourbon through out. Very sweet from the malt. Very complex. You can also taste the wood. Palate finishes very chocolate malt with the wood. Overall, easily one of the best beers I have had. Would live to get some more.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

UPDATED: JUN 24, 2014 Reddish brown pour. Aroma is malty, boozy and candi sugar. Taste is malty, caramel, vanilla, coconut,  oak, bourbon and boozy. Starts smooth finishes harsh, boozy. A sipper of a beer. Very good barley wine, strong.

Pours a dark amber with a light head and very little lacing. Aroma of chocolate, raisin, coconut, licorice and malt. Very similar notes to parabola but thinner mouthfeel, vanilla, oak, coffee, chocolate and coconut. Delicious barleywine, find it and enjoy it.

Very dark brown, mahogany hues on edges, off white thin head. Nose is vanilla, tobacco, chocolate, coconut. Flavor is same plus toffee pudding, roasted hazelnut, amaretto, apple-y British ale esters, mild earthy hoppyness for balance.

Bottle pour. Aroma of bourbon, slight hints of chocolate and vanilla and some malts. Taste is great. Lots of booze but not too overpowering, vanilla and chocolate and a boozy aftertaste. Palate bourbon, vanilla, a lasting chocolate middle note, some cherry and a boozy finish that lingers.

From a 0.65l bottle @ Copenhagen Beer Celebration 2013. It¬ís as good as clear in the glass, lovely dark wood-brown with a little bit of bronze in color and it has some small particles floating about and a small sidesticking top that¬ís lacing nicely do the sides of the glass. Oh, woody bourbon aromas here. It¬ís sweet, a bit sticky perhaps. Dark dried fruits and traces of red sweet apples. Smells really nice, not super duper extreme but balanced and nice. Nice soft sticky and oily on the mouthfeel with a small prickling carbonation level. It¬ís a big beer this. Tons of flavor, but it¬ís so e how hard to tear the different flavors apart. Feels really balanced and integrated. Not to much of a trace of the abv really. Some bitter nuts, lots of dark sticky caramel, some bourbon, a little bit of vanilla toward the finish. Yeah, this is world class. 04.05.2013

Bottled @ Zeebra #2. Sampled 5cl. The aroma has raisin, wood, bourbon, caramel. Clear, amber coloured beer with a thin head. The taste is quite sweet, has raisin, caramel, cookie, dark fruits. Bit alcohol warming in mouthfeel. Very nice.
Amazing beer. First barleywine I really enjoyed. Lots of wood, dark fruit (cherries), a little vanilla and caramel. Plenty of bourbon, roasted malt. Not much head. Sipper.
Draft at frisco¬ís taphouse. Pours reddish brown with low head. Aroma is rich sweet malts and bourbon. Taste is similar with a big oak and bourbon finish. Real nice

On tap at Frisco Taphouse. Brown with an amber tint. Very little head. Oaky, bourbon aroma with cherries and chocolate. Big malty start. A lot of bourbon flavor, oak barrel, raisins and vanilla. Very flavorful and complex.
Dark brown thin head. Aroma: vanilla chocolate bourbon a hint of licorice. Flavors to match, mouth coating with an alcohol presence but not boozey. Vanilla toffee finish.

Bottle courtesy of Lectvay, thanks a million! Beautiful copper pour with a light beige head. Aromas of oak, bourbon, dates, raisins, brown sugar, plums, and fig. I wish I had a candle that smelled like this beer it smells incredible! Taste is sweet dark fruits at first with notes of vanilla and molasses. Slight pipe tobacco notes in there as well. Just amazing. Slightly warming from the abv in the finish but just the right amount. A true gem.
Clear dark mahogany pour with a cream colored head. Strong molasses, vanilla, wood, and bourbon aroma. Taste is brown sugar, vanilla, wood, bourbon, and leather. Medium slick palate. Awesome.

UPDATED: OCT 23, 2014 shared bottle with 2 friends. poured a brown / dark ruby colour with a small off white head. vanilla, caramel, bourbon, bourbon soaked raisins, red fruits, oak, wood, some toffee, . this stuff is so balanced. there¬ís that bourbon kick, but it¬ís perfect in every way. silky smooth mouthfeel. incredible!
Amazing pull with the bourbon. Not too overpowering but with plenty of bourbon on the nose.
Very sweet with notes of dark chocolate, raspberries, and molasses. Wish I had a dark chocolate cake to pair with it.

On tap at the Common Table. Poured a clear dark brown with a frothy cream top. Taste of oak, slight chocolate, sweet caramel malts, boozy, vanilla esters, and dark fruits. Medium carbonation, medium body.

Dark brown pour with small off white head. Not much on the aroma, some roasted malts, oak, bourbon. Taste of roasted malts, toffee, caramel, coconut, chocolate, vanilla, dark ripe fruits in the background. Strong bourbon notes overshadow the true greatness of this beer. I wish they would tone down the barrel aging a tad so that it compliments the beer instead of dominating, nonetheless excellent beer.

02-MAY-2014, draft @CBC, Blue Session.
Clear, dark amber. Aroma is a bit on the weak side. Taste i shuge hops, caramel, nuts, bourbon. Big sweet body. Fantastic barley wine.
Backnote, had this beer at the zeebra extreem beer festival 2014. superb beer, cookie raisin dark fruit
@zebf 2014 - Hazy brown colour. Aroma and flavour are strong on sweet malts and dried fruit. A touch of Cognac perhaps.
Bottled @ Zeebra #2, small sample. Copper color, short head. Aroma of raisin, cookie, biscuit. Lots of malty sweetness in taste. Slight hint of alcohol. Big sipper. Nice.

At Zeebra Beer Festival, THX to everybody sharing today¬ís beers.
APPEARANCE: clear dark brown beer, small unstable off white head.
NOSE: caramel, sweet, alcohol.
TASTE: caramel, very sweet.
What an amazing beer. Body of sweet malt and dark fruits like raisin. Has delicious herbs and fruits like vanilla, cacao and cocos. Complex, balanced, rich and simply delicious.

Tap. Reddish brown body with an average, lacing, off-white head. Aroma of caramel, chocolate, vanilla, wood and coconut notes. Sweet flavor that ends up more dry and slightly bitter and with alcohol. Medium bodied, creamy to syrupy texture and soft carbonation. A world class Barley.

Toffee/caramel colored Barleywine with big bourbon and malty tones. Little heat on this which I feel would blend in over time. I don¬ít smoke cigars but if I did this would be an ideal accompaniment! Complex, deep oaked flavors with a vegetal/fruit feel.

22 oz bottle, 2014 vintage- Pours very hazy dark orange to brown with a thin head that I had to force that reduces to a collar and a few islands. Aroma is prominent vanilla, coconut, toasted masrshmallow, getting honey, massively complex and wonderful. The taste is very similar, strong coconut, vanilla, caramel, not overly bitter or harsh like most barley wines seem to be. Body is thick and chewy yet easy drinking, tasty shit for sure! At this price ($8.99 a bottle plus 10% discount!) I really wish i¬íd have picked up a few more for the cellar.

Tap @ CBC 2014. Pours deep red chestnut with a small, creamy, off-white film head. Aroma has toasted caramel, vinious, plums. Apples, strawberries, soft resin. Medium carbonation, fat and creamy mouthfeel. Flavour has good caramel sweetness, plums, apple candy, vinious. Fresh, warming.

Poured from bottle in to snifter. Very dark brown with very little head. Tons of bourbon on the nose. Very boozy, but not too much. Drank very smooth for a 14% beer. Had a very delicious vanilla/oak finish.
Bottle from Deeblo during London Bimble; dark copper pour with thin head, big boozy aroma, taste is brown sugar sweet has a big bourbon hit, with hints of cherry and apple.
660ml bottle. Pours dark brown with a small head. Aroma is minty caramel and molasses. Taste has caramel to start with molasses and a minty bourbon finish.

Bottle at London Bimble thanks to Bruce. Bourbon bourbon bourbon
 Not much beer. Ok bourbon

Bottle on London Hickster day, thanks to Bruce. Pours a dark amber colour. Huge figgy, rummy, dark fruit aroma. Full body, medium carbonation. Boozy, with big sticky dark fruit, rum, a little whisky... Lovely balance, rich and delicious. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

On tap at BB Rovers. 
Pours dark maroon to brown with no head. Looks muddy and still. Smell is caramel, dark fruit, sticky vanilla, Chinese food and soy sauce. Taste is a bit sweet with caramel and vanilla but finishes thin and dry with little aftertaste. Booze is hidden surprisingly well, but as it warms it quickly becomes hard to drink more because of the aroma and flavor than alcohol. Almost no carbonation. I didn¬ít even want to finish the last 1/2 of my 7 oz pour. Everybody else is jerking off on this beer, but I¬íd rather have just about anything else.

On draft at Simzy¬ís LB poured into tulip. Nearly opaque chocolate brown with a tan ring that revives with a swirl of the glass. Aroma is of coconut, dried fruit, bourbon, caramel, brown sugar, and vanilla. Taste is outstanding with strong fruit and caramel sweetness and mild barrel wood bitterness. Full body, silky texture, surprisingly moderate carbonation, and a sweet boozy finish. Excellent!
A solid barley wine poured a dark amber with aromas of booze, toffee, caramel and malt. Flavors are the same boozy aftertaste.

UPDATED: JAN 24, 2015 2013 bottle share. Clear dark brown with settling specs of sediment. Aroma of brown sugar, fig, plum, raisin. Taste is sweet and easy bitterness. Gritty smoothness. 2011 bottle share. So fuckin syrupy still, in the best ways.

650ml bottle into a shaker glass; served cool.

Aroma: Maple, brown sugar, booze. Soy sauce? Butterscotch.

Appearance: Translucent, dark, blood-red body with no head. Little to no lacing.

Taste: Lots of caramel and butterscotch. Not bitter, slightly sweet.

Palate: Rich, medium+ body with a little bit of prickly carbonation. Long, bittersweet finish. Ends on a sort of chocolate.

Overall: Excellent. Just delicious, excellent barelywine.

Draft at Good Dog. Slighty hazy burnt caramel pour with a slight off-white head. Have only had in bottles several years ago (then as Abacus) so now only rating upon this draft in April 2014. No surprise though - it is fantastic! Rich, heady and complex Barleywine. Molasses candy. Vanilla bourbon cigarettes. Milk chocolate grenache. Brandy drenched plum pudding. Dried blueberries. Burnt celery hearts. Fogs and liquorice. Toffee habeneros. Potent, but notably smooth for a 13% ABV. Very well blended malty dark fruit with a touch of chocolate and a spicy pepper finish. Different year to year, but never disappoints.
Bottle thanks to webbshoney. Nose of toffee and booze. Taste is lots of sugar and burnt toffee. Minimal head. A little but of boost in this one. God my reviews suck

2013 vintage. Dark brown with reddish hues, small brownish head, fading pretty quickly. Big malty aromas of caramel, tobacco, plums , spice box and dried raisins shining. Medium to full body, alcoholic at first with intense bourbon and liquor on the palate. Long warming and sweet finale with some vanilla and cherry notes. Almost like drinking a fine bourbon. Pretty nice stuff.

On tap at Holsteins in vegas. Vanilla, bourbon, butterscotch. Deep reddish orange with minimal head. Smooth bourbon, sweet dried fruit, really drinkable for the %. What an awesome beer. Soo complex. Over the top. Firestone walker is kicking serious butt with the big beers.

Aroma is plums, confectionary sugar, molasses, raisins, 
Very light bodied, cinnamon, vanilla, smoke.
Very nice body to sweetness balance. A really nice barley wine!

Poured from tap to glass. Brown hued with nice white head that dissipated to a thin ring. Aroma is roasted malt, caramel, figs, raisins, sugar, biscuit. Mouthfeel is nice with a medium bidy and nice carbonation. Taste is initially sweet with a slightly astringent bitter following and ethanol finish . Overal this is a great Barleywine that runs the border between an Emglish and American.

2012 bottle poured from a bomber into a Firestone Walker snifter a mahogany brown with a tan head that stayed around a bit longer than other "serious" English barley wines.
Aroma is booze followed by a sweet vanilla molasses.
Flavor is straight up sugar adoration. A blend of coconut, dark fruit, booze, chocolate. WOWza.
The balance of with higher ABV is bull eyes perfect. DAMN!!
Again another top 5 barley wine bucket list. So glad to have this beverage & another 2012 laying down like a good soldier.

This is one fabulous Barleywine. Drinking a 2012 bottle poured into a Firestone Walker snifter. Aroma is bourbon and vanilla yumminess. Appearance is a semi transparent reddish brown letting just a bit of light pass through it. Head was 1/2 finger and a light tan in color. Taste is bourbon, vanilla, cherries, prunes, and liquorice. Palate is very pleasant with the just right amount of carbonation. Overall a great BW and at the top of my top 5. A sipper for sure. The alcohol will catch up to you over time. Pairs great with peanuts and yes peanut butter. :)

To be honest this beer seems a little redundant, as the concept is similar to their Double DBA. But there are some differences - this one has more molasses. Lots of oak as well. A great oak-aged barleywine that doesn¬ít really taste like a barleywine (lots of imperial stout character). Very strong & complex.

On draft. Aroma of bourbon soaked raisins. Bourbon, dark fruit, and slight bitterness on taste. Sticky and sweet finish. Damn good

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

UPDATED: APR 7, 2014 2013 release. Bottle from Brewsters bar, LA. Caramel brown appearance; looks like a spirit. Aroma is bourbon and hops. As it warms barrel really takes over in the smell. Taste begins with bitterness then becomes sweet bourbon with a dry finish. Barrel flavour is primary, especially as it gets closer to room temperature. Bit of butterscotch coming out here as well. Don¬ít think I love this one. Something sickly in the taste - might be the big bourbon sweetness mixed with the bitterness.
On tap at Beercraft. Pours a dark brown color without much head. Burnt sugar and molasses. Alcohol harshness. Mild hops.

[Bottle / 2013 / Batch 003] Muddled, almost completely opaque dark-ish brown & rusty copper body, capped with a small, off-white & beige tinted film that transcends neatly to a thin collar. Aroma is quite complex, standard barrel aged barley wine notes of raisins, booze-soaked dates, bourbon lathered oak staves, mild vanilla, rustic caramel, sweet black cherries, burnt toffee, & prunes smothered in a sweet, lightly burnt, brown sugar glaze. Definitely lots going on, commanding presence. Taste is the same, with lots of bourbon & oak soaked notes of dark fruit; prunes, raisins, dates, & a touch of licorice. Hints of maple mid-palate with a barrel induced vanilla presence, warm caramel, a mildly tannic finish, & a wispy note of anise left on the tongue. More prunes, raisins, & bourbon covered dark fruits as the beer warms up with a more boisterous bourbon presence & a big, balancing, brown sugar sweetness throughout. Sticky, warm, thick. This is definitely a monstrous barrel aged barley wine & a damn fine one at that... but I still think it may be slightly overpraised. I¬íve definitely had more enjoyable -bal BW¬ís.

UPDATED: MAR 1, 2015 Pours a dark amber brown color with a off white head. Bourbon, cherry, vanilla, oak, coconut and roasted malt aroma. Vanilla, oak, coconut, cherry, plum, chocolate, roasted malt and some alcohol flavors. Full body and mild carbonation. Vanilla, oak and bourbon finish. 2013, 2014

Reviewed from notes.
The appearance is dark brown (almost black) with light red highlights around the edges, one finger white foamy head slowly concaves and clings to the sides of the chalice, some light clingy lacing spider webs a bit but falls eventually.
The smell has the bourbon up front - very powerful with some charred oak, vanilla, black licorice, light tobacco, light chocolate, and light raisins.
The taste is mainly sweet and sticky through the previously mentioned flavors, light caramel coming out. There is some sweet sticky aftertaste with a sweet dry finish.
On the palate, its about a medium to heavy, not sessionable - this is one to be sipped as the alcohol is felt pretty well. There is an adequate carbonation as well.
Overall, this is a very well done beer that I would love to have again.
Pours a dark mahogany. No head. Aromas are sherry, dark fruit, brown sugar. Flavors are sweet, vinous, and boozy. Sherry, raisins, and big booze at the end. Phenomenal.

Excellent barley wine! Poured an amber color with little head. Very tasty and extremely smooth compared to the ABV. Delicious!!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Tap at barrelworks. Very dark brown, minimal foam. Rich, caramel, toffee, fig, aroma, sweet. Chocolate, caramel, light molasses, a nuttiness. Pretty hot. Pretty solid.

(bottle) pours a murky deep ruby-brown colour with a small beige head. aroma of caramel, brown sugar and fudge, heavily oxidized, with a hint of mango and lots of alcohol. flavour is mostly the same, lots of yeast, caramel and bread crusts, lots of oxidation and surprisingly not very boozy at all. heavy-bodied with average carbonation.

750ml bomber given to me brought by ck1 for the Thousandth Night, and shared with ck1 and Jan. Thanks bro! Pours a dark brown/orange with a bit of a tan head leaving light streaks of lace. Aroma has roasted malt, sweet fruits, toffee, oak and vanilla, with light chocolate/coconut. Taste has toffee, sweet fruits and nuts, vanilla and a solid oak presence. Medium to full bodied and very sticky. Finishes sweetly long with a faint presence of bitter fruits. An excellent take on the style - perhaps the best had.

poured from the bottle at braukunst live 2014, very generous pour for a measly 2 euros. rich reddish brown with a very slender but lasting head; aroma of rum¬ín¬íraisin chocolate and vanilla; plenty of sweetness but never getting too sticky with plenty of gooey caramel and bread and butter pudding. i guessed it as being about 10% of well-disguised alcohol - now, seeing the true percentage, i understand why i started to feel a little tipsy after this one. very pleasantly so, i should add
Bottle share thanks to DrewFace. Pours cloudy amber, brown, no head. Aroma of malty sweetness. Taste is smooth, alcoh well hidden. Boosters on!

Bottle at the Triad bottle share at Foothills organized by Mike. Awww yeah. Luscious toffee and bourbon notes with some syrupy vanilla extract. Moderately smoky and surprisingly dry for a barleywine (in a good way).

Bottle, in a sniffer, amazing dark ruby color with a tiny thin head that leaves a ghost of a lacing. Mind blowing nose, cherry, oak, coconut, hits of alcohol. Mind blowing taste, my bartender (female) said "toasted coconut mouth sex, morphing into a pseudo chocolate covered cherry", can¬ít say it better myself. Yumm...

Bottle at Josh¬ís Farewell Fling, big thanks to Bruce for whipping this one out, 20/02/14.
Lightly hazed dark amber/chestnut brown with a well appointed light beige head that thins to a covering.
Nose is dark toffee fudge, coconut shavings, dark fruit tang, cake mix, cramelised sugars, praline notes, subtle alcohol notes.
Taste comprises mellow dark fruits, coconut, rich dark toffee notes, light booze, raisens, dates, brown sugar.
Medium + body, fine carbonation, lightly warming alcohol in the finish.
Solid barley wine, ticks all the boxes, alcohol well integrated.
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text:
UPDATED: MAR 15, 2014 From notes, consumed on 4/9/13. Bottle (2013) poured into a Belgian snifter. Pours dark brown with half a finger of off-white head receding into a ring around the glass. Aromas of dark fruit, coconut, booze, bourbon, vanilla. Tasting notes of dark fruit, oak, vanilla, coconut, bourbon. Warm boozy finish. Medium body with a semi-dry finish.

Had a bottle of 2014 on 3/15/14 and it was pretty much as I remember in my 2013 notes. ABV was upped from 12.5% for 2013 to 13.5% for 2014.

Bottle (2013) poured into a Belgian snifter, consumed on 3/16/14 so around 14 months old I believe. Pours dark brown with just over a finger of off-white head receding into a ring around the glass. More dark fruit on the aroma, faded notes of bourbon, coconut, and vanilla. Tasting notes of dark fruit, dark chocolate, light bourbon, light coconut, light vanilla. Still very enjoyable with a year on it but I prefer this one fresh with the bolder barrel character.

A big thanks to Bruce for opening this bottle for my going away. Always appreciate an off the list beer and what a way to finish. Pours very dark brown, clear on the edges, with a dense khaki head. Nose is very dark fruit forward with pleasing additions of vanilla and coconut. Slight ashy with some woody notes which help bring the sweetness in the aroma down. Taste is very much balanced coconut and vanilla, the barrels work a treat here, bourbon never overpowering. Nice addition of spice on the back end to the stewed and brown sugar laden dark fruits. Balanced superbly for such a big beer. I can see the comparisons between this and BCS, but as I¬ím a sweet tooth I think I prefer the BCS. This is still a world class beer though. Absolutely fantastic

2/20/2014. 22 oz. bottle from Belmont Station in Portland, OR. Pours dark brown with a short tan head. Aromas are sweet malt, oak, dried fruit. Flavors have noticeable alcohol, fruity, sweet with chocolate and vanilla.

On tap, poured a dark brown w/ thin tan head. Big boozy aroma. Initial flavor is bold sweet w/ a mild bitter finish. Tastes are prunes, aged cherries, brown sugar, Belgian sugar, Belgian yeast, oak, and plum.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Vintage 2014. Deep brown, relatively carbonated for the style, smells nutty and like honey, taste is sweet, molasses, butter. Feels just a little light and fizzy for a barleywine and with such rich flavors, but it¬ís really quite nice.
UPDATED: FEB 17, 2014 Red mahogany pour with a tan head. Rich yeasty aroma. Malty bourbon taste with hints of caramel. Soft dry finish with a woodsy aftertaste. Great barlywine.

Purchased in CA and drank in TX; actually labeled as a 2011 Abacus. I am sure the almost 3 years of aging made me like it more. Not a big aroma - malt, toffee, dried fruit, wood. looks like whiskey/alcohol in the glass. Taste is sweet, but NOT cloying. dried fruits, toffee, vanilla and an alcohol drying finish. extremely complex; I know this is an outstanding beer but not sure this is my style
22oz bottle. Pours a clear deep mahogany with a brief light tan head. Big caramel oak and vanilla aroma. Malty vanilla flavors. Dry smooth finish. Some ABV burn but not much nice.
Draft: Poured a murky dark brown. Sweet malts fills the nose. Nice dark fruits, figs, and malt.

Boxed bomber. Aroma is packed with toasted coconut first, then almonds, wet river rock, caramel, earth. Pours hazy amber with a collapsing beige head. Taste is sweet and savory, like what cashew brittle might taste like in heaven, if I can say that without sounding like a pretentious asshole. No? I can¬ít? I don¬ít really care. This is so good. Licorice pops out after it warms a bit. If this represents the new guard in the modern definition of barleywine (and I think it does), I¬ím all for it. Flat out, knock you on your ass delicious, just like all the FW barrel-aged components of the Anniversary blends. Pretentious or not, everything comes together near perfectly here. If this had a better head formation, this would be complete perfection. This is what I look for in a five star beer.

Pours crimson dark ruby, huge bourbon and burnt sugar in the nose. Mouthfeel is creamy, medium-full body with a bit too aggressive carbonation; flavor is bourbon, caramel, butterscotch, vanilla; , oak; gets better as it warms up. English style all the way; no hop presence worth speaking of (I prefer English style BW, particularly for the barrel aging versions).

I would have liked to see this beer a bit thicker in body, with a less frizzly carbonation, and a rounder finish.

Finish is definitely strange, something almost skunky or medicinal about it  which I am not liking at all. 

Finish aside, a superb beer, albeit very much overrated and flawed.

Pours strong. Light head that fades fast. Smells like butterscotch and toasted molasses. Tastes show more oak than expected. Residual sweetness and heavy malt profile take away all bitterness. Tasted somewhat like banana bread. Surprised me to not be at all hoppy as a Barleywine.

2014 vintage 22oz bottle - Pours a gorgeous deep mahogany with a creamed coffee head. Melted butter mixed into brown sugar, crem√© brulee, subtle cocoa, oak, and boozy rum for aroma. Flavors are bourbon oakiness, slight coffee and earthy hops. Drinks very smooth for being current vintage, one of the best Barleywines.

2014 Vintage, draft at the brewery. Aroma is dominated by oak, bourbon, caramelized brown sugar, toffee, caramel, amaretto, light booze on the exhale. Very complex, sweet and inviting. The beer has a slight reddish brown color with minimal head and big legs. Taste follows aroma fairly closely but with more raisin-y, coconut barrel character. Excellent waves of malt, caramel, amaretto and maple on the tongue toward the finish. Body is a bit syrupy with medium to medium-high carbonation. There is a slight burn on the finish, but it works really well with the sweetness to cut it down a bit. Definitely my favorite vintage.

2000th review! Got in a trade with cyde. 22 ounce bottle into snifter; 2013 vintage, bottled on 1/9/2013. Pours lightly cloudy dark ruby brown color with a small dense light khaki head with good retention, that reduces to a thin lace cap that lingers. Aromas of big vanilla, molasses, toffee, caramel, raisin, toast, chocolate, coconut, oak, bourbon, tobacco, clove, and toast/oak earthiness. Incredible aromas with fantastic complexity and balance of malt and barrel notes; with great strength. Taste of huge molasses, vanilla, raisin, caramel, toffee, toast, coconut, chocolate, oak, bourbon, tobacco, light clove, and toast/oak earthiness. No bitterness on the finish; with lingering notes of molasses, vanilla, raisin, toast, caramel, toffee, coconut, chocolate, oak, bourbon, tobacco, and toast/oak earthiness on the finish for a while. Insane complexity of malt and bourbon barrel flavors; with a perfect malt/barrel flavor balance and zero cloying sweetness after the finish. Light-medium carbonation and full bodied; with an very creamy, slick, and slightly syrupy mouthfeel that is amazing. Alcohol is very well hidden with only a light warming present after the finish. Overall this is an absolutely insane BA English Barelywine style. All around insane complexity and balance of malt and bourbon barrel flavors; and extremely smooth to sip on for the high ABV. Absolutely unbelievable stuff, Wow.

the best barley wine I¬íve ever had. It¬ís just a joy for the senses. It pours with a lot of color and body, holding the glass to the light reveals deep, warm blood-red and cherry, with plum and bronze when the light hits the edges of the glass just right. There¬ís no real head, and at almost 13.5% alcohol, I didn¬ít expect a lot of suds. The aroma is nose music. Cherries and figs, ginger, chocolate, and something in there reminds me of granny¬ís cornbread (maybe the highest compliment I¬íve ever given a beer). And what this beer does for the mouth is even better than the smell. I¬ím not a wine guy, but this brew reminds me of the few red wines I¬íve enjoyed. It¬ís rich, smokey, very, very full and warm. I picked up on strong chocolate, anise, espresso English walnuts, and a little burnt popcorn thing, too. There¬ís something that reminds me of Nutella in the close, after the swallow and exhale. It¬ís so complex, but all of it blending and harmonizing perfectly. Barley wine can be sticky, viscous, and that¬ís the quality about the style that I enjoy least. Sucaba has a big mouthfeel, but it slides away smoothly and leaves you to ponder the last sip and crave the next, in much the same way that my favorite Belgian quads finish. This is the best beer I have had in more than a year.

UPDATED: FEB 19, 2014 Three Part Cellar Review
Part III
Sucaba bottle, bottled January 3, 2013.
Appearance: The body is clear with a great ruby to mahogany hue. The head is thin with poor retention that settles into a thin ring.
Aroma: On the pour the nose is nicely balanced with coconut, oak and bourbon coming through. After it¬ís sat for a moment the coconut is dominate with dark fruits and toffee backing it.
Taste: Sweet malts on the intro with a strong mid-taste of bourbon, oak, coconut and brown sugar. This is a bit hot at the moment, but very drinkable.
Palate: Thick with a syrupy texture and moderate carbonation.
Overall: This is great, there¬ís no doubting that, but after my vertical it seems that Sucaba is best with a few years on it. This is very drinkable fresh, but it certainly benefits from a year or more on it.
Part II
Sucaba bottle, bottled January 5, 2012. ~1 year old.
Appearance: The body is clear and a deep mahogany with garnet hues, a beautiful color. A thin tan head foams up briefly, but settles quickly into a thin foamy coating.
Aroma: The aroma is strong on the oak at first with a touch of bourbon on the first smell. Upon swirling I smell some booze, vanilla, and faint coconut coming off a bit musky.
Taste: This is very sweet and syrupy right away with a strong toffee flavor intertwining with dark fruits. The oak and bourbon are very light, only appearing on the finish that lingers a bit after the sip coming off a bit hot.
Palate: Thick and syrupy with slightly sharp carbonation.
Overall: This comes off a bit too oaky and unbalanced on the nose than the 2 year old one and a bit unrefined in the flavor. It¬ís great, but it isn¬ít as good as the 2 year old one.
Rating: 7, 5, 7, 5, 15
Part I
Abacus bottle, bottled February 18, 2011. ~2 years old.
Appearance: The body has good clarity and a beautiful garnet/mahogany hue. Little lights comes through the body, it¬ís very dark. A short tan head escapes the body but quickly settles into a foamy ring.
Aroma:The aroma is sweet, a touch musky even. Brown sugar and toffee dominate the nose with dark fruits. The barrel notes are subdued providing a light vanilla and a touch of oak, very little bourbon is noted.
Taste: Very sweet, this drinks like a cognac. Lots of caramel and brown sugar with medicinal dark fruits overlying the sweet syrupy thickness. The finish has a bit of alcohol, hinting at the bourbon, but very mellow with a lingering syrupy fruit finish with a strong coconut presence.
Palate: Thick and syrupy, light carbonation.
Overall: I had this fresh once and from memory I think fresh is better. This is excellent though and has certainly aged very nicely. I think of this as sipping on a nice cognac rather than a beer. Well done.
Rating: 8, 4, 8, 5, 16

Batch 1 Abacus bottle to oversized snifter (thanks, daknole!).  Looks good; boozy with low CO2 and thin lacing.  Smells AWESOME!  Big, sweet, and boozy!  Tastes good too; vanilla, caramel, and bourbony (almost brandyish, but I think that¬ís just the sweet influence of the base beer).  This is great stuff!

Bomber. Pours a dark copper and mahogany color with a half-inch of cr√®me br√ªl√©e foam. Lots of potently strong and sweet bourbon, caramel, vanilla, oak and black cherry notes round out the aroma. The flavor starts with a heavy dose of caramelized sugars, dark fruits (candied dates, figs, raisins) and toffee before the bourbon, oak and booze kick in. Also in the mix are some coconut, plum and cocoa flavors. Mouthfeel is silky smooth and medium-bodied with soft carbonation and a final blast of sweet bourbon in the finish. Overall, one of the top barrel aged English style Barley Wines and an ideal sipping beer to savor.

2011 Bottle "Abacus" thanks to vtafro: Pours a clear deep copper amber with a clingy-lacing off-white head.  Has a rich sweet caramelized sugar nose with good bourbon vanilla character and light fruity complexity. Starts with a rich, full body and light carbonation with plenty of initial sweetness revealing lots of complex brown sugar, vanilla and raisin flavors with a splash of bourbon before a slightly warming semi-sweet finish.  Hides the alcohol fairly well and has good balance of flavors throughout.

Nose of fruit and caramel.  Dark ruby pour. Figs, bourbon, vanilla bean and a hint of oak.  Big alcohol on the back end.  Lasting warmth and burn to finish.  Sweet and complex, this is one I¬ím going to hoard.
Bottle.  I knew this was going to be a serious beer.  Pour murky brown with a tan head.  Aroma of bourbon, caramel, dark fruit.  Very sweet and there is vanilla in the flavor as well.  Well done.

On tap at Firestone Walker event with David Walker at Capones. Pours a deep deep murky crimson brown. Barely any head or lacing. Aromas are very impressive due to the three year aging in heaven hill bourbon barrels. Aromas of vanilla, oak, chocolate malt hints. Taste is so layered and rich with toffee, black cherry, candy sugar, caramel, toasted coconut. Boozey but I wouldnt expect anything else for a 12%+ barley. Aftertaste is bready, sweet malts, and slightly smokey tobacco. Amazing barleywine.

UPDATED: AUG 20, 2012 Bottle. Pours a nice dark amber color with a tan head. Aroma is super complex filled with barrel notes, I get lots of coconut and oak, bourbon like notes, vanilla, dark fruits, tobacco, toasted malt and chocolate. Flavor is equally complex and again filled with coconut and wood, I get vanilla, dark fruits, brown sugar, tobacco, toasted malt, chocolate, dark cherry and vinous notes. The body is full with a creamy mouth feel. Overall an amazing Barley Wine, probably the best I have ever had. FW never sizes to amaze me!
I thought I had this back when it was Abacus but I guess the database doesn¬ít lie...bottle shared at pre-DLD evening. Tasty with big notes of vanilla and coconut. Way too easy drinking for 13 ABV.
Bomber. Dark fruit and cherry mixed with alcohol and spice. A hint of chocolate. Sticky sweet finish with light bitterness. The sweetness gets to be a bit overwhelming.

Vintage bottle bought in July 2011 at the Jug Shop in San Francisco. 
Pours brown with no to low head
Aromas of caramel, roasted barley, vanilla, tobacco???, pepper
Mmm. This is good! A lot of vanilla, some bitterness and sweetness,...
This is a beer thst starts and ends the same. High sweetness, low bitterness, nice mouthfeel. Wow! Easily the best barley wine ive had!

Pours reddish brown with minimal tan head. Nose is caramel, barley, toffee, alcohol, vanilla. Taste is, well, first of all, absolutely brilliant! Opens up very sweet but with a subtle, and important, bitter backbone. Alcohol clearly present throughout. Slightly smoked barrel tones. Mouthfeel is incredible, very thick and rich. Best barley wine I've had.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Brother Jeff supplied in Peteluma. He didn¬ít like, too sweet. Is a bit cloying, and pretty warm with alcohol. Molasses and cherry, dark, very malty, and yes, sweet, hint of bubblegum. Close my eyes and this could be a port. Thick, light sourness lingers on palate, very nice.

In short: The archetypical American Barley Wine
How: Bottle, consumed 8 months after purchase, split 4-way
The look: Cloudy bronze body topped by a beige ring of foam
In long: Nose has a moderate barrels presence and leafy hops over rich caramel.  Taste starts with a wicked big rich caramelized malt backbone, just enough fruity flavors to increased complexity, vanilla, wood, toasted nuts and toasted cookies, enough resinous leafy hops to almost balance this monster beer.  Alcohol is a little apparent but seems rather fitting to warm up this monster body.  Huge body that doesn¬ít feel cloying or too heavy.  This is a superior example of the style.  The problem with this excellent beer is the hefty price tag, too pricey to make it a regular, and I wish I could make more money at work but so far I have failed to find a way to sleep my way to the top.
Tap at DLD12.  Whiskey, prune malt, and hay aroma.  Hazy brown color with minimal head.  Sweet prune malt and woody bourbon flavor.  A nice beer.
On tap at Dark Lord Day 2012. Sweet, boozy, oaky vanilla aroma. Murky brown with a small head. Syrupy sweet, boozy, oak, vanilla, prune flavor. Full sticky body.

Bottle shared at Dark Lord Day 2012 (Munster, IN). Pours a rich darker browninsh hue, deep with good lacing. Dies down to a film, small lacing. Aromas are rich spirit, bourbon and sweet caramel and toffee malts, touches of toast, vanilla, shaved coconut, oak. Gentle spirit, some sweet oxidation. Initial is sweeter and thicker, rich toffee and caramel, rich oak and spirit, gentle kisses of toast. Some warming elements. Initial is sweeter, toffee and caramel up front break way into toast, barrel elements, vanilla, and coconut, warming spirits grow. Spirit as it thins the body, warms the belly. Bourbon and whiskey, vanilla, oak, and toffee. Some sticky elements stick into the backend. Well balanced if a growing warmth into the back that might get a touch harsh. Still, it gives character and wins me over. Solid beer, light carbonation, good flavors and body.

pours a dark amber hue with a small white head that is mostly diminishing
aroma of dark fruits malt, molasses, soy sauce, alcohol
flavor is the same but with a chocolate after taste - unsweetened chocolate
thick mouthfeel with light carbonation
an amazing brew
Bomber. Pours brown with thin white head. Aroma is caramel, oak, vanilla and tobacco. Flavor is more of the same plus some leather. Delicious.

UPDATED: MAR 31, 2015 Poured from a bomber into a duvel tulip. Pours a dark ruby brown with a finger length beige head that shrinks to nothing. Average lacing. Aroma is dark fruit. Raisins, figs, plums, and malt. Taste is more of the same. Raisin, plum, toffee, caramel, and slight citrus notes. Mouthfeel is sticky and chewy. Amazing beer, can¬ít wait till i try a cellared one.
Initial rating 4/19/12

Update. Same beer, bought the same day. It¬ís been in the cellar ever since. 2012 edition. Rating date 3/31/15

The beer pours a ruby brown with a very thin beige head that immediately disappears. Aroma is oak, molasses, brown sugar, and a lot of dark fruit flavors. Raisin, date, and plum are there big time. There is also a slight spicy smell in the back and faint bourbon aromas. Taste is very complex. I¬ím having a hard time focusing on all of the flavors because they are so intense, yet have tons of subtleties. I get a lot of dark fruit. Plums, figs, dates, and raisins are all represented nicely. There is a caramel sweetness and a ton of molasses as well. It¬ís kind of like a holiday fruitcake. I also pick up some oaky notes in the finish. The beer is very sticky in my mouth and the flavor lingers on forever. I literally mean forever. I¬ím talking 5 minutes in between sips and I can still taste flavors of dark fruit and sweet molasses. It also gets rather dry near the end. This was a great beer fresh and even better after 3 years in the cellar. I just wish I aged two of them.

Pours a deep burgandy brown with a thin ring of off white head. Nose and taste are sweet of caramel, vanilla, a bit of woodiness. The booze is very well hidden in this brew and it is almost painfully good!

Bottle, 04/16/2012.  Pours ruby-tinged brown,  short-lived beige head, thin lacing.  Prominent wood and bourbon in the nose, caramel vanilla with coconut, wrapped around dark bread malts, touch of chocolate and dark fruits, subtle tartness. Taste is also barrel dominated, big coconut and molasses, dark grains and dried fruit, spicy character, bourbon vanilla booze to finish.  Full palate, silky and bordering on creamy, long aftertaste, alcohol doesn¬ít detract.  Pretty great barley wine here.

Boxed and black foil-wrapped bomber from 2012, opened in celebration of being granted permission to write my dissertation.  Pours garnet red and brown with a short-lived brownish-beige head.  Aromas of sweet bourbon, oak, butter, and orange/vanilla.  Dark fruit and some alcohol creep in as it warms.  The flavor is sweet, sugared fruit, soaked in bourbon.  Smoky oak, tons of buttery toast, and light berry are present, with moderate bitterness, cherry/bourbon, and burnt sugar in the finish.  Low/medium carbonation, medium/full body, warming, and creamy.  Really well done, delicious!  [1021]

Fine, I won¬ít tick, I¬íll rate this one. Dark brown mahoganey. The aroma was brandy, bourbon, cocoa, vanilla. The flavor was coconut, oak, vanilla, cocoa, faint slices, light fruits. Only flaw was a little heat. FW can do IT! Mouthfeel a tad light and lacking some carbonation spritz.

22oz bottle, 2012 vintage, purchased at Belmont Station. Pours a deep, dark, amber color with an off white head that fades quickly. Aroma is bourbon, vanilla, oak. A little syrupy on the palate with light, soft carbonation. Flavor is sweet, malty, vanilla, oak, chocolate, a little booze, with a sweet, bourbon finish. Very tasty.
Dark brown pour with thinnish head.  Aroma of bourbon and cocoa, with a flavor similar.  Cocoa and vanilla accent a big bourbon base.  Hints of oak and and vanilla.  Silky smooth.  Well done.
Pours a deep reddish brown with a tan ring of head. Aromas of dark fruit, vanilla, and alcohol. Taste is cherries, oak, molasses, and bourbon. Really outstanding.

22 oz. bottle pours a deep mahogany color with a small eggshell head. Huge whiskey aroma with dark fruits in the background. Taste is very potent with a huge sweet body. The oak notes from the aging process is phenomenal. Mouthfeel is pretty thick so definitely sip on it but an absolute prime example of not only a great barley wine but an amazing oak aged experiment. Find this.
Sampled at an esbls  tastong.  At 4 Hands.  Dark brown aque.  Dark rich malt nose with bourbon.  This is good.  So much flavor.  That bourbon is king here but dark fruit and so much malt.  Good.

22oz bottle.
Deep amber pour with some off-white head.  Aromas of vanilla, toffee, caramel, bourbon, oak, and coconut.  Flavors of dark fruit, vanilla, bits of chocolate, lots of wood and bourbon.  Crazy good!

Poured into tulip glass

A: Sucaba pours with a wonderful frothy light brown (think milk chocolate) head that is average in size (about 1 finger). It¬ís head diminishes without staying around long at all. There is some lacing but does not stick to the glass very long. The color is murky brown to ruby red on the edges and bottom upon holding it up to the light. 

S: Maple sweetness, vanilla, toasted oak, tobacco, and lots of bourbon. Wow lots going on here in the aroma. Next I get the dark fruits like raisin, plum and maybe some dark cherry. The sweetness is evident and wonderful. Brown sugar and toffee come to mind next. Lastly I do pick up some tobacco.

T: The taste does not disappoint and follows the nose like I was hoping! I first taste a wonderful combination of bourbon and sweetness that intermingle in perfect harmony together. The dark fruits (plum, raisin, prune and date) take center stage and then the vanilla and oak make their appearence. I must mention the alcohol is very much there and warms and stings the mouth and tongue urging me to take another sip!

M: This is medium on the palate but just right in my opinion. It is alcoholic like I mentioned in the taste but just awesome. Sticky comes to mind as I continue to sip as it does coat my mouth nicely. This allows the flavor to linger for a looong time and I¬ím lovin every minute of it.

O: King Henry is one of my favorite beers and let me tell you I¬íll take Sucaba as a decent substitute for the never brewed again King. This has shot to the top of my list of all time favorite sipping beers, but it is so hard to just sip this one.

22 oz bomber purchased at Royal Liquor in Kansas City, Missouri.  (2012) Vintage.  The pour is a deep brown, with light ruby highlights and a thick khaki head.  The aroma is vanilla, sweet toffee, caramel, malty, oak wood and warmly boozy.  The alcohol of the nose melds nicely with the giant malt aroma.  The taste is the big malt sweetness (vanilla, caramel, dark fruits) along with a really nice full leafy earthiness and mineral.  As with the nose, the alcohol complements the big flavors rather than detracts.  The palate is medium to heavy bodied, creamy, and has a pleasant lingering maltiness.  Generally I don¬ít love these gigantic Barley Wines, but this one managed to be big and classy.  Nice beer.
