Pours copper with a small beige head. Aroma is caramel, raisin, plum and alcohol. Flavour is caramel, sweet, raisin, plum, heavy alcohol and light hop. A litle to sweet.

Aroma of molasses, vanilla chocolate, and slight black cherry.  Pours brown and heavily carbonated.  Taste is intense.  Oak, chocolate, cherry and vanilla balance wonderfully in a malty bed.  Delicious.

(from notes just found)  On tap at Fourth Avenue Pub.  Dark brown with dense ring.  Maple syrup vanilla and wood aroma.  Toasted caramel maple syrup mild dark fruit vanilla wood with fairly clean finish and minimal burn.  Excellent.  On par with Angels¬í Share.

An excellent example of what a very good barley wine can be. Dark, brown with very thin head. Lots of toffee, butterscotch, chocolate and bourbon, sweetness, but not overdone. It¬ís like a dessert beer if there were such a thing. So good, it¬íll be a long wait til next year¬ís batch.

This is for Sucaba. Was lazy and never rated Abacus from bottle or tap. On tap at the brew house. Pours a black to deep brown with next to no head. Toffee, dark chocolate, bourbon and coconut in the nose. Taste is coconut, dark chocolate, some cherry and a light earthy note that I can¬ít place and don¬ít remember from the past batch.  Overall, bourbon forward barleywine that I wish had more hop profile being as "young" as you can really get.
user_location: Morro Bay via Orange County, California, USA

text:
Bottle from good ol' Nugget. Aroma is of Sam Adams Utopia...brandy/bourbon-alcohol soaked barleywine notes. Flavor has coconut, cherry and pipe-tobacco notes. This one was definitely hot on first pour. As it warmed, it was muy enjoyabley...actually, still muy enjoyabley! This is 12.5% Utopia btw...Damn good beer!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Best barley wine I¬íve had. Dark dark brown color, sweet aroma. Strong Bourbon taste when it¬ís cold but the flavors really show themselves after it sits for a few minutes. Wonderful sipping beer.

Bottle from Beer Heaven in Philly. Pours a ribbon of silky onyx with chestnut highlights under a rich dark tan head.  Aroma of molasses, butterscotch and lightly roasted coffee. Big, sweet, rich butterscotch flavor right up front that blends with toffee, milk chocolate, plums and other dark fruits all atop a hearty malty center. Creamy mouthfeel and a long, sweet, pleasing finish. Wonderfully complex but deceptively drinkable, especially with such a high ABV.

Poured in the appropriate small snifter at Surly Goat.  Very dark brown in color.  Big vanilla taste.  Extremely smooth.  The alcohol is not in your face.  I get some chocolate at the back.  Overall, a smooth sipper.

Pours a dark red with a small ring of bubbles. Aromas of oak, caramel, raisins. chocolate, tobacco and rum soaked cherries. Silky smooth, full bodied with some average carbonation. Overall a wonderful beer.

Pours a nice murky brown color. Aromas of booze, oak, vanilla and caramel. Flavors of caramel, vanilla, chocolate with a nice oak finish. Very nice beer and easy drinking for 13%, very tastey and smooth as silk!

WOW. This is an incredible brew, simply put. Pours dark, dark brown with a ta head. Aroma of toasted marshmallows, booze, caramel, and chocolate. Essentially, big, boozy s¬ímores on the nose, I guess. The palate is great as it mixes light carbonation and silky viscous alcohol. The flavors are nice and you can tell that this was aged in multiple barrels as you get some really nice complexities from the different barrels. This beer is very well-made, but at the end of it one thing remains true - BA Barleywines are just hard to make in a way that excels over the top. The Barleywine style just poses such a lack of complexity in the brew itself that it is entirely dependent upon the barrels. This was very well-done, and my hat off to Firestone. I would love to see a stout done like this.

UPDATED: JUN 13, 2013 650ml bottle 2012 vintage.

It pours a dark reddish brown with a fizzy but foamy tan head that actually sticks for a little bit and then recedes with no lacing.

The smell is great. Boozy and boubony, I am beginning to like hotter beers with more of a bourbon kick. This one has an ample malt and barelywine backing though, a ton of dark fruit, rich malt flavors, and a bit of hops shine through. The yeast character is indeed English giving it a profile that isn¬ít often had in big BA barleywines, usually they are more american yeast tinged.

This one is really thick, wow. It has a good vanilla, coconut, and oak vibe that is the main hit I am getting. Instead of boozy this one is as velvety smooth as it gets at first sip. The sweetness is never too cloying but it creeps up with the alcohol as you go. Nice hop, tobacco, and dark fruit flavors as well as a great malt bill. The bourbon itself is readily noticeable lending a spirit-like vibe.

This is an exhibition of how to make a bourbon aged beer.
Bomber in the dark, sweetness, chocolate caramel toffee molasses sugar cane , first a boozy sweetness, then the above mentioned .

2012 Scuba Steve edition. 22oz bottle served in a snifter. Poured a clear reddish brown with a quickly dissipating head. Lots of chocolate and vanilla in the aroma along with a bit of alcohol and some hops. Really complex flavor with more chocolate and a bit of bourbon from the barrels. Not as boozy as the nose might suggest. Medium bodied without much carbonation. Really long finish of chocolate. Way to easy drinking for 12.5 ABV! Fantastic.

Pours a murky dark brown body with a small beige head. Aroma of roasted malt, caramel, toffee, oak, chocolate, and vanilla. Flavor of vanilla, maple, caramel, toffee, bourbon, and chocolate with some oak in the finish. This is Heavenly!

Sucaba pours a dark brown with a small tan head.  No lacing and basically no retention.

When I poured this bottle I was instantly hit with greatness.  This smelled totally different than the first bottle I had.  Wasn¬ít even the same beer.  You¬íre hit with bourbon, oak, caramel, toffee, and vanilla.  It¬ís rich, deep, and complex.  I could sit here and just take it in all night.

The taste is just as amazing.  Sweet caramel and bourbon sit on the lips and coat the mouth.  Slightly roasted malt and vanilla dance on the tongue.  Vanilla and charred wood hit the palette mid way.  A slight bitterness hits on the end and aftertaste.  Just fantastic.  A different beast than the first time I had it and I can definitely say, have this as fresh as you can.

Mouthfeel is just as amazing as the taste.  On the thicker side, very sticky, coats the mouth and just sits there.

The beer pours a translucent, deep, dark ruby color with an average, khaki, pillowy head which settles to a fully lasting, firm, frothy layer and leaves some similar lace.  The nose is very nice, very smooth for a 13% beer; plenty of coconut, bourbon oak all over, Belgian chocolate, light peppery spice, faint cherry, toasty vanilla, and some tobacco.  The flavor is drastically different with a prominent spicy bourbon role that lingers all the way to your belly; tobacco, vanilla bean, toasted oak, molasses, light Belgian chocolate, some coconut, and a slight raisin note.  The palate is full, silky, creamy, warming, round, and soft to lively.  The finish is long, warming, oaky, filled with spicy bourbon, some coconut, and toasty notes lingering.  Where to begin...  Just a very well built, blended, bourbon-aged, strong, BW with unique character, unique complexity, and a prominent bourbon strength that only accentuates the uniqueness of the beer.  It was amazing how the nose was rich and smooth yet the flavor carried so much of the spicy bourbon notes and warmth.  This one was so smooth in the nose and bold in the flavor, it makes me curious how it will age.  But even with the high pricetag, I do want to try one in some years to see if I find it as entertaining as this version is.  Only time will tell.  Great work from Firestone.

Aroma is bright caramel apple, vanilla, oak. Woah. This is beautiful!
Taste is caramel, vanilla, strong, woodsy oak chips, booze, and faded piny hops.
Finish is sweet, slightly bitter hops, vanilla astringency, caramel, and some burnt sugar.
Wow.

Reddish-brown pour with a tan head. Aroma was sweet molasses, oak and fruity. Taste was so awesome. Fruity, woody, a little dry, sweet molasses. I drank this at cellar temp/55. The aroma and taste made you want to drink it slow so it wouldn¬ít end. The foam clung to the side of the glass.

From notes.
Poured to a snifter, deep brownish red almost a plumb color it held a half finger light tan head for about a minute that dissolved thin film and then to nothing.
Very rich aroma. Very sweet, dark fruits, burnt sugar and carmal. Just a little bit of alcohol.
First sip is I get a lot of sweet flavors blended together. Lots of sweet malt, tart strawberry, tiny bit of bitterness there is defiantly some alcohol in the finish which is paired with oak flavors.

Mmmmm this one is amazing.  Pours a mahogany color with a thin head.  Heavy smell of bourbon, sugar and hops.  Taste is very delicious.  Molasses and brown sugar with some hops.  Lots of bourbon.  Such a great taste.  Lovin¬í it.

650 ml botte;. Pours a dark reddish-brown color with a small beige head that quickly diminishes to a fine ring. The aroma is strong with whiskey, vanilla and dark fruits. The taste is complex with bourbon, vanilla, sherry, leather, raisins, dates and brown sugar.  The palate is full and smooth with soft carbonation. Finishes incredibly long with lingering tobacco and bourbon aftertaste. Overall: A nice little sipper, I wish I could get more.

Room was a little dark when poured so color was tough to judge. But there was very little head, and what was there disapated quickly. The nose is incredible, I could live in there. At first it¬ís overwhelming, but you can quickly go through the layers of complexity. Taste is similar, complex, wonderful. Like drinking a bourbon, wine, and beer all at the same time. The finish lasts for what felt like hours. The only negative is accessibility.

Bottle Courtesy of Wavers1, Thanks Baker!  A fantastic bourbon aged barleywine that has more flavor components then I could even pick out.  Vanilla, Leather, dark fruit, and a nice nuttyness.  Really good stuff here.

From notes.  First reviewed 12/26/2011.  Poured from a 22 oz. bottle into a snifter.

The appearance of this beer is more similar to an old ale than a barleywine. A dark chocolate brown is a bit transparent in the thinner parts of the glass. A small off-white head struggles to form originally and fades to nothing fairly quickly.

The aroma simply bursts out of the glass. Tons of vanilla, caramel, bourbon, oak, and a bit of spice.

The flavor starts out with a very nice and complex gooey caramel that never gets too intense or cloying. A bit of roasted malt, some spice, and then a smooth bourbon, vanilla, and oak presence that carries through the finish. Incredibly smooth and balanced.

Although the alcohol is well-hidden in the flavor, the alcohol creates a tingling sensation on my tongue and warms the back of my throat and stomach. The carbonation is pretty much perfect; creamy and moderate. Definitely on the full side of the body spectrum. Slightly sticky.

This is not one of those beers that has nearly infinite separate components; it is a relatively simple beer that is made impressively well. The bourbon really accentuates the wonderful flavors and adds some complexity itself.
Fuxk this is impressive. Same barrel aging as firestone parabola. Big sweet barley wine and one if my favorite barrel aging treatments

Bottle from 2011 pours a dark red brown with a small white head that goes away rather fast not much lacing. Smells and tastes of caramel, alcohol, soy sauce, bourbon,resin, medium sweetness, medium bitterness, medium body, sticky, average carbonation. Really nice smell and flavor on this. Has the nice caramel start with the bourbon in the middle finished with a slight resin hop bit to finish. Warms as it goes down to stomach. I wish I had more.

Bourbon dominated nose with vanilla, oak, and a strange fishy smell underneath. I swear this is a clean glass. Clear garnet, thin tan head. Flavor is less dominated by bourbon, but it is certainly present. Oak and maraschino cherry notes are more to the forefront. Plum also present. Boozy and full bodied. carbonation is easy. Abrupt, yet brief grassy finish. Very complex as is the norm with Firestone Walker. Quite sweet. I¬íd prefer it to be less boozy, drier, and hoppier.

Bottle.

Head is initially small, frothy, light brown, mostly diminishing.
Body is dark brown.

Aroma is moderately malty (caramel, molasses), with notes of sherry, maple syrup, brown sugar, bourbon, alcohol, wood, vanilla, tobacco.

Flavor is heavily sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter.
Finish is moderately sweet, lightly acidic, lightly to moderately bitter.

Medium to full body, syrupy/watery texture, lively carbonation, moderately to heavily alcoholic.

Well...it has the expected traits that score big points among most beer geeks...lots of alcohol, lots of sugar, and bourbon.  If our subculture can be pegged for anything, it¬ís for liking "big".  And this is certainly that.  It does have at least some depth and elegance underneath the primary sugary notes, though, so it¬ís not just a dumb sugar-bomb.  It attempts to balance the syrupy sweetness with booze more so than bitterness, but even so it¬ís still not all the way to being cloying...fatiguing, yes, but not Bruery kind of icky.  So, it¬ís a mixed bag...not my kind of barleywine, but in this vein you can certainly do a lot worse.
Deep ruby in color... Aroma is oak, bourbon... Flavor is extremely complex, notes of tobacoo, alcohol, sugars, oak, dates.... Very nice beer...

My first Rate ever!  COOL

Looks pretty dark, reddish when held up to light.  Light off white head that dissipates to a ring for awhile then disappears forever. 

Smell is a bourbon bomb. Vanilla comes through but mostly boozy, bourbon whiskey. 

Taste is bourbon, booze, heat, bourbon, bourbon, vanilla, bourbon, caramel and some malt. Did I mention Bourbon?

Mouthfeel is ok, a bit thin I think. Not as sticky as I would have liked. 

Overall this is good if you like the fresh heat and very prominent bourbon taste. Look forward to stashing one for a year or two

My Bottom Line:
Strawberry jam, wood, caramel and alcohol heat coalesce in this classy behemoth, as leafy hop bitterness builds a levelled finish.

Further Personal Perceptions:
-A ring of foam circles the blood red.
-The soft effervescence gives a lot of room for the malts to express themselves.
-The mouthfeel is not too fat, which I appreciate. I would not call this a lean Barley Wine either though¬Ö
-The flavor profile may be powerful, but all flavors remain in line.
-This was not a most m√©morable Barley Wine, but it remained a mighty efficient example of the style.

Bottle.

Bomber at Jerry¬ís. Dark amber with whispy tan head / Big nose of coconut, oak, toffee, chocolate / Full body, sweet, slightly hot but with good balance and long finish / Flavors of semi-sweet chocolate, toffee, butterscotch, dark cherry, dates, coconut, hazelnuts, oak, and bourbon / Fantastic.  Give it a year.

Abacus 2011 Version
Tasted on 3/7/12 from a 650mL bomber bottle purchased at Sun Devil.  Pours an opaque dark amber with a thin tan head that leaves thin, even lace.  The nose is dominated by caramel, toffee, coconut, and vanilla bourbon, with tons of oak, and a touch of sweet, wet tobacco and unidentifiable fruits.  The flavor is just the same, with the dark fruits and wet tobacco, moving to caramel, toffee, vanilla, coconut, and oaky bourbon.  The body is full and oily with just lighter than average carbonation and a long caramel, toffee, and oaky bourbon finish.  At 13% alcohol, this beer is scary drinkable.

What a nice brew, thanks to NorCalgrowler for this one. Aromas consist of a lot of vanilla, some brandy and bourbon, cherries, alcohol, light molasses. This one pours out a nice brown body with ruby accents and a khaki head. Sweet. Taste wise, this one is insanely appealing with loads of bourbon, caramel, molasses, butterscotch, dark fruits, and chocolate. A fine BA barley wine that everyone needs to try at least once! Cheers!!

Crrrazy brew thanks to OmegaX. It pours a nice ruby body, and a nice plush off-white head that is very appealing. Aromas of cherries, molasses, cocoa, bourbon and vanilla entice the senses - quite the complex scent. With a mouthful of caramel, chocolate, cherries and brown sugar, this brew is complex and intense as it warms up. Finishes with a hint of wood and bitter/dry hops, the palate is complete on this one. Yay.

Mine says Abacus. It¬ís older. Very dark mahogany colored pour. Nice, medium-sized, khaki head that fades quickly and leaves just a bit of lacing. Huge peppery, woody aroma. Smells of bourbon, malt, dirt, and wood. Taste is big on pepper, vanilla, bourbon, malt. Smooth, sweet, with a slight alcohol presence on the back. Does not drink like 13%. Better watch out if you have more than a couple on hand. They are that smooth. Excellent beer.

This is an absolutely exquisite barleywine. It has an understated bourbon and vanilla blend up front. There is a gradual transition into sweet chocolate & caramel malts with dark fruit spices coming out in the finish. The taste is amazingly clean, with no lingering sweetness or booziness; which is surprising because it has an abv of 12.0%

Bottle @ Aarons place, Thanks. Pours dark brown with a small offwhite ring of foam along the glassides. Aroma is malty, caramel, bourbon, toffee, vanilla, dark fruit. Taste is full and very complax with malts, caramel, toffee, rich bourbon flavors, oak, vanilla, plums and other dark fruit. Full body, low carbonation, rich lasting sweet oaky bourbon finish. Fantastic. 020312

Bomber bottle. Nice dark pour with a thin head. Smooth delicious flavor. Sweet bitter cherry with some chocholet. 
Enjoy

UPDATED: APR 24, 2012 Poured from bottle to a snifter. Medium brown to golden amber in color. Almost no head- some creamy tan bubbles on the side of glass. Nose is lots of vanilla, alcohol with notes of sweet bourbon. Oily mouthfeel and surprisingly thin for my expectations. Initial taste is vanilla, dark toffee with hints of caramel. Again, lots of bourbony sweetness with a good alcohol burn. Long finish. A great and incredibly complex beer!

Beautiful aroma of oak, vanilla, bourbon, fruit, molasses.   The appearance is a cola brown, slightly translucent, thin light tan head.  The flavor is oak, vanilla, chocolate, molasses.  The finish is booze warming, sweet bourbon, pine needles.  The booze is a little too much on the palate and in the flavor.  Maybe a year of aging would really do wonders for this.  Medium/thick in body.  Beautiful.

Amazing. 2011 vintage. Dark brown color with a thick white head. 6oz snifter. The nose shows roasted nuts, a variety of pit fruit and some spice. Layered and complex palate showing figs, mocha, citrus and berries. Perfect mouthfeel and absolutely no heat on the long finish.

UPDATED: APR 5, 2012  Pours a ruby red/brown with fine lacing. Aroma is of dark fruits, caramel, and bourbon. Flavour reflects this, highlighting the bourbon as the main characteristic.Really sweet to begin with, but very well balanced with a woody after taste. Lovely.

Dark brown-publish color with thin white head. Aroma of chocolate malt, biscuits, maple syrup and bourbon. Taste is...hello flavor country, we¬íve got a whole lot of complexity going on here: Vanilla, raisins, toasted malt, molasses, bourbon.  The finish has another layer of oakiness followed by a tart sweetness. Surprisingly light body for a barleywine. More please.

Sampled at the prebrewvival tasting.  Clear amber brown pour with ring of tan head. Complex dogfood, scotch, chocoate.  Flavor of leather, honey, dark chocolate, smooth booziness. Oaky vanilla finish.  Red wine characteristics.  Good complexity, but it wasn¬ít really taylored to my personal taste or anything.

At HallingHansen Grand Tasting, thanks for sharing. Pours a clear and dark brown beer with a weak offwhite head. The aroma is malt, sweetness, fruit, dried fruit, vanilla and wood. The flavor follows the nose with additional alcohol. The palate is sweetness with alcoholwarmth. Overall a really good beer.

2012 release, new name, same beer.  Bottle pours clear reddish brown with no head.  Aromas are faint, and a a little booze and some wood.  Taste is chocolate, booze, oak, caramel, some fruit like raisin or black cherry, and vanilla.  Very complex, very delicious. Not overly sweet or dry, not overly hopped.  The complexity really makes this beer.  Body is medium and a bit thin, but the beer is viscous and pretty highly carbonated.  Overall, a delicious beer that is great as a sipper.

Moyenne effervescence en bouche. Pr√©sence de caramel en arri√®re go√ªt. (Rating #4145)

Bottle shared by alexsdad06. Poured clear reddish brown color with a minimal frothy off-white head that mostly diminished with little lacing. Moderate to heavy chocolate, wood, coconut and small alcohol aroma. Medium to full body with a smooth texture and soft carbonation. Moderate to heavy complex chocolate sweet flavor with a medium to heavy sweet finish of moderate to long duration. This is another standout beer.

2011 vintage.  Incredibly rich, sweet, malty aroma, full of dark sugars, faint bourbon, vanilla, cherry, almost roasted caramel sweetness, cotton candy, wood, fiery alcohol and raisin.  Deep, cloudy mahogany color, head forming a fine ring around the edge of the glass.  Flavor shows a profoundly rich, caramelized sugary sweetness, dark, dried fruits, bourbon hints, more vanilla and oak along with dark chocolate, nut, brown sugar and cocoa appearing at the finish.  Low in effervescence but still buoys the huge flavors well, smooth, thick, syrupy and warming, body is just gigantic.  Incredible stuff, avoids being overly sweet and cloying, somehow.  Highly impressive.  Absolutely made for wintertime and for Barleywine fans such as myself.

On draft at the Livermore Saloon. This has everything you could want in a barrel aged barley wine. Often, these American versions can be way too overpowering with the booze and heavy bitterness, but this is just so tasty, you don¬ít notice any of that. It pours a reddish brown with a thick tan head. The aroma is ultra complex with caramel, toffee, cherry, vanilla and wood. The flavor is pretty much the same with an insanely rich body and smooth on the palate. Yes it¬ís boozy, but lower in bitterness than I remember Abacus being. A tremendous fireside sipper!

Bottle at Yazoo Fortuitous release. Pours deep copper brown with a beige head. Aroma of vanilla and caramel. Medium to full bodied with a slight sticky texture. Flavor of caramel and vanilla, but with a spicy bitterness and nice wood nuance. Sweet without going over the top. One of the best barleywines I have had in a long time.

Hey, someone poured a Knob Creek in my Oaked Arrogant Bastard! Brown with ruby red highlights, small head and sticky oily lace. Bourbon is strong on the nose, accompanied by vanilla, coffee, and hints of chocolate and dark berries. The bourbon is gigantic on the palate, almost overwhelming the caramel malt, chocolate and dark toasted bread. Medium body, minimal carbonation, sticky mouthfeel, hot alcohol and the bourbon lingers smoothly.

Got this at bevmo, they where jusy taking it out. It pours a very dark red with a small white head. Aroma is of caramel, alcohol, sugar and oak. Taste is of oak, toffee, sugar, plums and rasberries. Mouthfeel is stick and sweet. Overall this an excellet marriage of beer and barrels. I usually dont care for barely wines but thanks to this im gonna seek the style more.

UPDATED: FEB 15, 2013 Pours a reddish brown color, with decent head, and aroma of malt and carmel. Taste is moderately complex with notes of carmel, malt, wood, alcohol, a little vanilla and hops. Not sweet, and does have a slightly harsh bourbon and alcohol edge to it. Finish is bourbon, alcohol and bitterness, all in balance, and all lingering. A barley wine for those who dislike sweet malt or massive bitterness, and like booze. Worth trying every year, but would like just a little more complexity to this.

Update: Sampled bottles at 2 years and at 1 year. Dries out over time, and is probably best consumed young.

Brown with a small off-white head. Malty aroma of toffee and biscuit along with vineous dried fruit notes, some vanilla and oak. Sweet caramel and toffee dominated flavour with a creamy/milk chocolate character. Lots of oak and lots of alcohol in the finish
Sweet vanilla and coconut. Oh so inviting. Little bit of bourbon on the mouth but follows the vanilla and coconut. Pretty amazinh
Bottle. Redish body with a small offwhite head. Aroma is sugar, caramel, dark fruit, oak, bourbon. Flavor is caramel, sugar, raisins, bourbon, dark fruit, oak.

Pouring at the Night of the Barrels on the Friday night of EBF 2012.  Pours a clear ruby with a thin to medium sized beige head.  Sweet malt, brown sugar.  Oxidized malt, toast.  Medium bodied, lots of oxidized malt.  Plums and malt, toast.  Lingering alcohol, plums and oxidized malt on the finish.

Sample Coles Barleywine Competition 2012. dark copper, rather flat, little head. Tons of complexity. Oak, vanilla, raisins, rich maltiness.Big big flavor. Barrel aging really shines here. Very enjoyable

Abacus bottle shared by motortoddhead.  Deep red-brown with fading head.  Awesome aroma of earthy, must oak, dark cherries, sweet caramel, toasted malt, syrup, and mild booze.  Flavor is sweet cherry, plum, brown sugar, syrup, oaky goodness and finishing with light bourbon and more malt goodness.  Some mild alcohol residual.  Lingering cherry, vanllia.  Thick and sticky.  Amazing!
Sticky sweet barleywine with lots of bourbon character. Thick and caramelly. Another port winish BA beer

Bottle at hallinghansen grand tasting. Pours hazy dark reddish brown with a medium off white head. The aroma is loads of dark fruits, tobacco, bourbon, vanilla and oak. The flavour is dark fruit, chocolate, oak, tobacco, berries and has some boozy notes. Dark fruity finish. Bit too boozy.
dark chestnut, thin cream ring. Nose is cocoa, roast, caramel, and heat. Flavor is caramel and sugar, light booze through finish, bit of wood and heat, heavy sugar chewy throughout.

Bottle shared at a tasting - Pours cola color with a ring of tan head. Pretty sharp and boozy on the nose. Sweet malty notes, but really hard to tell cause this one is so hot. Taste is the same--hot and oaky, with toffee and caramel, but lots of strong, sharp heat takes over and remains through the finish. Butterscotch on the long finish. Burns the mouth a bit. Wow...this was terrible, and I was expecting it to be fantastic.

Bomber thanks to PintPlease.
Appearance : Deep clear amber with small white head.

Aroma : Big sweet malt with fruity hops. Light resinous notes. Very light oxidation maybe. Light licorice.

Taste : Licorice with sweet fruity plums and raisins. Awesome caramel with some resinous hops. Finish has a lot of raisins with light resinous hops. Not much alcohol.

Overall : Wow this was good. Awesome sweetness balanced with the resinous hops ans the light alcohol. Delightful caramel. The Bourbon is not very present but adds to the complexity and to the richness. Very well balanced and very tasty. My kind of Barley Wine.

Smooth, Creamy, vanilla. The palate is very smooth, thick, and very warming, this fills your throat with heat. Color is deep brown, cloudy. Aroma of sweet brown sugar and fruity tropical nectars. Shared at Curtis¬ís (Nashville¬ís Sweetwarer Representative) tasting.

UPDATED: APR 7, 2014 2011 bottle enjoyed around release time. Brownish copper pour with streaks of white head and lacing.  Nose of caramel, toffee, malt, and all of the usual BW suspects.  Taste adds vanilla, and darker fruits.  Slight bitterness that will likely go away with time.  Good BW.

Updated - cracked a 2011 on 4/7/14.  Aging has not really added anything to this beer.  If anything it has maybe lost some of its original sharp tasting notes.  Now that I have had several BA BWs I find this to be a bit thin in comparison.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle, 2011. Pours a dark clear brown with a thin offwhite head. Smells phenomenal. Brandy. Lots of malt. Dried dark fruits. Cream. Vanilla. Wood. Sweet something I cannot identify. Cotton candy?. All very mellowed and insanely drinkable. Tastes very sweet, b t tempered with some balanced bitterness and Bourbon smokiness. Full bodied. Soft to flat carbonation. Finishes cloyingly sweet. A very interesting beer, and one I¬íd happily drink again.
Aroma coffee, roasty.  Appearance brown/black, tan foam. Taste heavy bourbon sweetness. Palate  full body, soft carbonation.

UPDATED: JUL 26, 2013 26 July 2013, tap at Firestone Walker Barrelworks in Buelton, CA.   (2013 variety) brown and clear at the edges. Nose is granola, faint syrup, slight tartness, mild alcohol. Thin, syrupy body and moderately fizzy. Crime br√ªl√©e, milk chocolate, some bitter chocolate notes, syrup, moderate alcohol, very smooth. 

(Original rating 8 3 8 3 16 = 3.8) 30 dec 2011, bottle. Cloudy but brown. Nose is neat; Oaked Whisky, coca-cola, spiced malt. Med body and almost flat. Rich, oaky raisin malt. Really neat. Rough but rich. I like it.

Bomber. Deep amber/brown liquid with small off-white head. Aroma of vanilla, wood, bourbon, caramel, toffee, chocolate and biscuity malt. Taste is light to medium sweet, medium bitter and malty. Very oaky. Notes of caramel, wood, vanilla and coconut. Full bodied with OK carbonation. Delicious BW, lots of character from the barrel aging and the malt.

Bottled, thanks baggio!  Hazy mahogany colour. Oaky caramel aroma. Sweet and massively full bodied. Sweet and intense with oak and vanilla on caramel. Warming and soothing. A big beer for slow sipping.

Pours dark brown with a ruby tint and just small amount of tan head. Smell: A huge malt profile, toffee, chocolate, some cherry, vanilla, caramel and  booze. Caramel, chocolate, toffee, vanilla with a touch cherry. Palate is thick and coating with a long malty booze and cherry finish.

UPDATED: SEP 1, 2012 2011 Abacus, batch 1 served in a brandy snifter. From 11/18/2011 notes, reviewed 12-23-2011.

A - Deep red/brown body. Small white head which quickly dissipates to a still body. Legs, but there is minimal lacing or retention.

S - The bourbon and oak are very dominant. The finish is fruity. Caramelized figs and plums and sweet malts.

T - Alcohol is dominant but smooth and not overpowering. Taste is heavy on the bourbon and dark fruits. Medium carbonation and body. Maybe lighter than I would have liked.

O - A very delicious barrel aged barleywine. The only fault I found was that I wished the body was a bit heavier to support the flavors.

2012 ¬ßucaba (the beer formerly known as Abacus), Batch 2. Poured into a tulip glass and reviewed on 09-01-2012.

A - Same as the 2011 but with a longer lasting head.

S - So chewy and toffee heavy. Smell is just very much in the english style with some fantastic barrel notes of bourbon heavy vanilla. Finishes with an alcohol warmth and some caramelized fruits and some spice.

T - Chewy toffee, burnt caramel, vanilla, oak, dark fruits. Still just as tasty as the first batch. Mouth feel is also still a tad on the light size.

O - This beer is very much a booze bomb. Its one of the hottest beers I¬íve ever had, but it works the same that a fine bourbon or scotch works. You just sip and enjoy the deep complexity. Its very english with a strong and chewy toffee aroma and flavor that seems to meld right into strong bourbon barrel notes. This remains to be a top three barleywine for me.

bottle. pours dark brown off white head, nose maple syrup vanilla, booze. flavors are loaded with maple syrupy goodness, charred bourbon barrel, oak, vanilla popping, cocoa nibs, long booze finish but it¬ís rather mellow, yummy stuff

bottled, thanks to SS, dense walnut color with some thin foam ring, looks very big and boozy, great aroma of maple syrup, waffle malts, hot alcohol, flavor is oaky malt , whiskey cake, lots of brown sugar, slight cherry finish with more alcohol, another nice FW

Bottle from a trade with cbkschubert. Pours dark brown with thin tan head that dissipates quickly. Sweet toffee and bourbon aroma with some chocolate, oak and a hint of coconut.  Sweet toffee and lots of bourbon flavor with vanilla, chocolate,  oak and coconut.  Full body with minimal carbonation and a slick mouthfeel. Awsome beer! Thanks Craig.

Thanks GT2! Extreme dark brown pour with a thin tan head. Massive vanilla bourbon, caramel, toffee, maple syrup, marshmallow, and tannic wood abound. Sweet and boozy with a thick body and low carb, finishing sticky.
Sample. Rating #225. Clear dark brown pour with a thin head. Sweet caramel aroma, light hop aroma. Dark fruits, light bitterness and full on joy, real freaking nice. (2025)

Taste is the same, and finishes in cherry cordial notes, with boozy warming. I could drink this at room temperature, and be quite happy. $15/220z (celebratory: "Modernist Cuisine" arrived)

Edit:  Now that it¬ís called Sucaba, it seems a bit hot and harsh in the alcohol department, without the mellow refinement I recall from before.  Still very good, but just not great. Rating stays, along with my fond memory. (celebratory: Rammstein Concert!)

Bottle shared by a friend. Clear brown pour with a medium beige head. Aroma of caramel, toffee and booze. Flavor starts with English toffee and cherry, then moves to sweet caramel and bourbon before a malty chocolate finish.
Poured 22 oz into a sniffer glass. The Abacus has a burnt caramel color.  Oak favors with a hint of coconut, which goes well with this big boozy beer.

651mL thanks to peteinsd. Pours a flattish clear deep mahogany. Yellow bubbles. Looks like FW10, FW11. Nose is big maple, toasted coconut, toffee maltiness. As it warms it exhibits more savoriness/umami with rich coconut. Taste is rich, big coconut bourbon, lovely dessert profile with mild heat. Not too much sugar, beautiful coconut. Very beautiful palate- not too sticky with a nice fruit juicy character and mild sugar. Super yummy dessert beer. Similar to FW11. Shame it doesn¬ít pour with a head. Moderate alcohol heat is not distracting at all. Still, Parabola is the Cuvee de Firestone.
Bottle courtesy of GT2, thanks!  Depp and clear ruby color, small beige edge head. Aroma is boozy vanilla and pancake syrup. Taste is carbonated tawny port, whiskey, dark fruits. Very nice.

This beer pours a hazy ruby-brown color with a medium beige head that recedes steadily. Small patches of lacing. Aroma of oaky vanilla, dark fruit and brown sugar. Rich body with flavors of chocolate malt, vanilla, booze-infused fruit and a little smoke. The finish is ripe fruits and dark chocolate. Good beer all around.
750 ml bottle pour.  I really enjoyed this one.  Dark amber color with a nice head.  The sweetness goes well with the bourbon.  Very smooth.

Dark amber, small frothy tan head. Aroma of light bourbon, soy, molasses, leather, nutty toffee, rum soaked fruit, woody bitterness. Taste is mostly sweet with some woody earthy bitterness, light cola flavor and a light alcohol taste. Really silky texture, not much carbonation. One of those beers that has an aroma that is so good that I don¬ít even want to drink it. This beer seriously reminds me of a really complex Belgian Quad like Rochefort 10 or a Belgian Strong like Pannepot without the Belgian yeast and with Bourbon barrel instead, The aroma is very complex and the flavor is very strong yet filled with nuance.

UPDATED: MAY 26, 2012 2011 vintage. Bottle @ home, courtesy of foppa78 into my new Cigar City snifter, courtesy of markwise. Thanks guys! Very deep brown/ruby appearance with a tiny tan head that dissipates in no time. Really a nice, smooth, tobacco, fig, plum, caramel-toffee malty, somewhat sweet aroma that¬ís exquisite. Tobacco, date, plum, fig, dark fruity, moderate toffee, lighter caramel, fairly malty, bourbon, somewhat woody flavor. Dark fruity, cherry, plum, toffee aftertaste. No hint of the 13% booze- are you kidding me??? In a way, it kind of reminds me of HOTD Matt in its complexity. Simply unbelievable.2012 vintage. Bottle @ home. Last time around I was blown away by this baby, so I¬ím really looking forward to trying it again. Dark reddish brown appearance with a brown head without much lasting power. There¬ís initially some notes of booze in the nose which isn¬ít all that unpleasant. Besides that, rich toffee, thick caramel malts, vanilla, oak, mild to moderate bourbon, and dark fruits (fig, plum) are also noticeable in the aroma. Creamy, nutty, rich caramel/chocolate malty flavor initially that is like tasting a liquid turtle chocolate candy. More vanilla, oak, and bourbon towards the back of the mouth and despite the overall sweetness of the beer, it¬ís balanced incredibly well. There¬ís also notes of tobacco, fig, and vanilla with a warming, dessert-like finish. Simply unbelievable. Easily one of the five best beers I¬íve ever had.

Tap at pap. 3/18/11

Tastes like bs,oak and medicine pills.

Dark auburn-ish porter brown. No head.

A= wood, near burnt caramel, barrel spices, florals, floral alcohol,


F= the same plus very noticable alcohol, toasted nuts, chocolate, malt, berry like fruityness, vanilla. Very mild bitterness on the finish.  

Lighter feeling than expected but still a bit oily... 7.5/4/7/3/15... tastes like ba bw

A - Dark brown, ruby highlights, thin sheet of off white head.
S - Brown sugar, raisins, and alcohol.
T - Molasses, vanilla, figs, leather, and alcohol.
M - Creamy carb and dry, with a warming sensation.
O - A slight let down. The nose is pretty one dimensional, and the alcohol is detected pretty easily. Definitely not the best BA English Barleywine, but pretty good.

This pours a dark mahogany color with a thin bubbly head that quickly gets shoved to the sides.  There¬ís still some thin spotty lacing that slides along the sides of the glass after each sip.  Mostly bourbon, caramel, and plum in the aroma but also notes of leather, tobacco, and licorice.  Sweet and smooth going down with quite a bit of caramel and toffee malt flavor to go with oak barrel notes.  There¬ís certainly a lot of controlled bourbon boozy flavors here providing plenty of warmth.  Tobacco, cherry, and vanilla integrate nicely.  The carbonation seems about right.  A gentle alcohol sting sits on the back of the tongue but this drinks probably about as smooth as 13% can.  Nice stuff, one to be enjoyed slowly, very good.

GABF 2011. Clear almost ruby nutty brown, no head. Nose of bourbon and oak, along with vanilla extract, dark ripe fruit, earthy toffee malt. Drinks like an oak aged port, with soft plum and raisin tones, with nice medium booziness, with a warmth on the finish. Huge palate coating body. Has some burnt dark malt tones to it, with a touch of tobacco, big toffee malts, lots of dark fruits, and oak. Big all around.

Bottle 22fl.oz.Clear dark red brown colour with a average to large, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white head. Aroma is moderate to heavy malty, caramel, tobacco, laberlaver, alcohol, sweet tobacco, ripped dried fruit. Flavour is moderate to heavy sweet and bitter with a long duration. Lovely ;O) Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20110930]

I¬íve been wanting to try this for awhile but haven¬ít found the right opportunity to open one. Well, as of 9pm tonight I¬ím on vacation for four days so the time is now. Thanks to Brian (BrewerB) for this bottle, which I received in a recent box.

This one pours a nice and rich cherried wood in color with a light and fizzy khaki colored head which quickly dissipated. The aromas consist of sweet and ripe dark fruits, figs, light bourbon, oak, vanilla, raisins, and port. It smells pretty good but I could use more bourbon. The flavors are almost exactly what I was looking for tonight. You get a lot of buttery biscuity malt (yet not as intense as a California Chardonnay), light bourbon, oak, vanilla, raisins, figs, and it has a rich and resonating after taste. The bourbon is a little more mellow than I anticipated but it¬ís fine. Overall this is a fine beer and a pretty spectacular barrel aged barleywine. It¬ís an instant favorite and probably my second favorite of the style to only the Mother of All Storms.
Bottle. Brown/red with tiny off-white head. Aroma is malt, fruit, caramel and toffee. Flavour is fruit, caramel, sweet, little rip fruit, toffee, hops, oak, dark fruits and a little bitter.

Bottle @ Morten minus Peter smagning, Ulfborg. Pours ruby amber with a small creamy white head. Nose is oak, caramel, fruit and chocolate. Flavor is oak, vanilla, caramel, dried fruit and vague alcohol. Complex and quite a sipper.

fonefan tasting. Hazy reddish brown with an off-white head. Aroma is sweet malty, caramel, dried fruit, tobacco and alcohol. Flavor is quite sweet and moderate bitter. Dry and moderate bitter finish. 300911
Bottle @ fonefan tasting. Nice head with good duration. Color is red/brown. Aroma and taste are malt, fruits, spices, alcohol, wood, caramel and hops.

Bottle 2011.  Aroma has notes of bourbon, oak, vanilla, chocolate, dark dried fruits.  Dark brown that sits almost black in the sniffer.  No head and no lace.  This beer looks like flat coke.  Flavor is very sweet.  Palate is very full bodied and oily soft.  Overall a good bourbon bomb Barley Wine that smells and tastes great but looks like shit.

Poured into a snifter glass. Aroma is slightly alcohol. Flavor is malty, chocolate, vanilla. Palate is nice, I really wanted to mention the whiskey after taste and heat that gently comes back up and warms you. This is great as I don¬ít really drink many barley wines I don¬ít have to much to compare to, but I love it!
Bottle at Paps√∏¬ís - Thanks to Anders37. Clear red/brown - white head. Borubon, vanilla, wooden, fruity, lots of vanilla, caramel, roasted, barley notes, medium malty, coconut. Smooth and Lovely.

UPDATED: SEP 22, 2011 750ml Bottle:  Complex aroma of oak, dark ripe fruit, plum, malt, slight red wine, toasted caramel, slight coconut, and some vanilla.  Poured very deep amber/brown in color with no head at all.  Cloudy.  Slightly sparkling.  Full of tiny and small-sized particles throughout.  Flavor is medium to heavily sweet and slightly bitter.  Tastes of malt, coconut, slight alcohol, vanilla, light Bourbon, light toasted caramel, and some dark ripe fruit.  Medium to full body.  Oily, slick texture.  Average carbonation.  Malt, dark ripe fruit, coconut, light Bourbon, light toasted caramel finish is a tad sticky.  13%ABV is slightly noticeable in the flavor, but not hot or overwhelming.

22oz bottle picked up at west lakeview... Pours a dark cola mahogony pour  with reddish edges and topped with a thin film of light off-white head... Aroma is sweet sacharine with dark fruits, fruitcake, a vanilla smooth oak aged bent with tobacco and chocolate to go along with it... Flavors follow suit closely wit tobacco, booze, barrel and ripened dark fruit.  A little heated but defintely a nice sipper. Thicker bodied than expected but decadent in its own way.

22 oz. bottle from Grape & Gourmet (purchased in April 2011).  Pours a cola-like brown with a thin layer of quickly fading bubbles.  Incredible aroma of bourbon, vanilla, oak, dark chocolate, coconut cake, dark fruit, and probably some other aromas I have missed.  Incredibly smooth flavor showcasing the bourbon, vanilla, and coconut and with layers of chocolate and smoke underneath.  Every bit of the 13% alcohol is felt in the warmth yet this is a surprisingly thinner offering than you would expect from a beer with this complexity and depth.  As it warms the background flavors find their way to the front just a bit more.  This is an outstanding offering from an outstanding brewery.

Bottle at Paps√∏, thanks Anders.
Clear red coloured with a small off-white head.
Sweet and fruity aroma of vanilla, oak and dark chocolate with roasted notes.
Sweet and fruity flavour of caramel, oak and vanilla with notes of dark chocolate and roasted notes.
Sweet and roasted finish.

Poured into a snifter. 2011 vintage. Thanks to psiweaver for this.

3.5 A: Clear (I think) deep brown, nearly black color. One finger of fizzy head falls quickly and leaves no lacing.

4.5 S: This nose has it all and by that I mean it has a big hit of bourbon AND a very respectable beer underneath. The bourbon is lightly leathery with perhaps a touch of peat. Also included is a moderate fruitiness that borders on the floral, good bit of vanilla, and nearly as much oak. Lots of caramel and toffee with plum, prune, date, and fig fruitiness. Brown sugar and a very reasonable booze level for the ABV. Really complex and pleasant. Borderline 5.0. 

3.0 T: I can¬ít believe what I¬ím tasting. This beer has such a nice nose, but the taste is straight up boring. Boozy bourbon with a light charred, peaty flavor. Still a decent amount of vanilla and oak. The beer itself is the problem with the taste. The taste follows the nose for the most part, but all the dials are turned down to a three from what were eights. All subtlety is lost behind the booze. Really disappointing and certainly not better than average. 

3.5 M: The mouthfeel is indicative of what is problematic with this brew. A 13% barleywine had me thinking thick, velvety, and rich. Having had Parabola a few times, I figured that was the route this would go as well. Instead, this has a medium body and a moderate creaminess. Seems like the potential malt flavor went away with the potential heavy body. Not bad, but not what I was expecting. 

3.5 D: Totally disappointed. I loved the hell out of Parabola and thought this would be the barleywine version of that. It isn¬ít. Not quite sure how this is getting the scores it does. Maybe bottle variation. Who knows? Not confident this will age well, but I have another bottle and I¬ím going to give it a go.

clear brown, no head.
rather mild aroma, malty, nutty.
flavor is nice , lots of wood, vanilla, malts, spices, sweet and spicy barley wine

Bottle 65 cl. Courtesy of anders37. Pours amber with a slight haze and an off-white head. Sweet toffee, overripe fruit and heavy sweet oak. Very solid body, thick caramel notes, overripe fruit and sweet, luscious Bourbon. No real bitterness but quite some warming alcohol. Delicious. 080911

22oz, boxed and black foiled bottle, dated 2/18/11 from grape & gourmet. pours a beautiful, hazy, mahogany with a smooth, thin beige head that has great retention and leaves sticky drips of lace on the edges. aroma is outstanding with rich, sticky dark fruit notes of fig, raisin, and red berry backed by brown sugar, toffee, and light floral esters with the subtle bourbon barrel notes of oak, vanilla, tobacco, and toast emerging as it warms. flavor is wonderful as well with bold, boozy notes of bourbon, toasted oak, and toffee up front backed by sweet dark fruit notes of black cherry, plum, and fig with subtle notes of angel¬ís food cake, toasted malts, and creme brulee on the finish. palate is rich, full bodied, and perfectly carbonated with a great balance of sweetness and boozy, bourbon warmth. overall, a great barrel aged barleywine.

Bomber.  Poured clear, fiery garnet with a lovely, but unfortunately short-lived beige head.. great color and clarity.  The aroma was powerful, with sweet and delectable bourbon, tobacco, and dark fruits over a rich base of molasses, drawn caramel, maple, and vanilla bean.. the barrel was very well integrated.. loved it!  The flavor found a warm base of darker fruits, molasses, and maple.. black pepper, vanilla bean, aged oak and tasty bourbon around.. vanilla and bourbon led the drive through the finish.. earthy and peppery at the end, but the alcohol balance was perfect.  Heavier-bodied with low carbonation on the palate.. spicy and engaging throughout.. excellent feel and flow.  This was a masterpiece, and I¬íd love to try it again sometime.

Bottle pours thick amber brown with a very brief tan head that fades quickly to a ring.  Sweet aroma of malt and bourbon.  Big taste of sweet caramel malt followed by oak and bourbon.  Hints of tobacco and vanilla.  I would describe this as an American Strong barleywine.  The front is typical sweet barleywine followed  by almost a umami flavor with the tobacco and bourbon. Very nice beer, reminds of a stronger version of Founders Backwoods Bastard.

Tap, Black Squirrel. Poured with little to no head, bar¬ís fault on a darker muddy ruby brown body. Toffee, prunes, toast, caramel, and a bit of fruity sweetness in the aroma. Dark prune flavors, not a major hop presence but some leaves, raisines, toffee and caramel. Warming, medium body and coating.  Would be a great nightcap.
Pours brown, with a tan head. Aroma is bourbon, malt, and fruit. Flavor is bourbon, malt, alcohol, fruit, brown sugar, and vanilla. Fairly on the heavy side.

UPDATED: JUN 9, 2012 A: Deep brown black body. Tight khaki head. Quickly receded into a thin collar. No lacing.

S: Bourbon, vanilla, oak, caramel, a little generic alcohol fumes.

T: A very restrained bourbon barrel barleywine. Certainly plenty of flavor from the bourbon barrels, but nothing abrasive or hot about this offering. Lots of oaky vanilla. Rich malt backbone.

M: Silky smooth medium-heavy body. Just a pinch of heat in the finish. Appropriately carbonated.

O: One of the best bourbon barrel aged barleywines out there.

22 oz bottle.  Dark brown with edgy tan froth.  Nose is caramel, dark berries, rum, fig and musty wood.  Medium to full body, slightly sticky, with a light tingle but still reminds me of cough syrup.  Taste is orange, cherry and bourbon.  Hints of chocolate, caramel, coconut and red licorice.  Oddly hoppy and vegetal with building heat.

This poured a medium brown colorw ith a beige head. Aroma was lots and lots of bourbon, but not much alcohol perse, caramel and toffee, vanilla as well.  Flavor much like the aroma, lots of bourbon there, sweet malt, can definitely get the nuances of the barley under the bourbon, and hardly any hints of alcohol either. Just great stuff all around!

Deep ruby red pour thin off white head .... aroma of vanilla, bourbon, oak and cherry .... amazing taste of oak, vanilla and bourbon some chocolate and tobacco little boozy with a malty backbone .... mouthfeel is smooth and very balanced with a bitter finish that lingers ... unreal

Served on-tap at Capone¬ís during the Firestone Walker Lunch party. Enjoyed with Dave Walker himself! Served into a snifter.

A - Pours deep brown with a thin film of white head, dissipating down to nothing at all, leaving no lacing down the glass. This was served WAY too cold. Once it warmed up a bit it got a little better.

S - Smells of warm bourbon, vanilla, dark fruits, tobacco, and chocolate sweetness offer some contrast to the typical caramel / toffee sweetness in most barleywines. The heat began to creep in more and more as it came to room temperature.

T - Lots of toffee sweetness up front quickly giving way to a mix of bourbon heat, tobacco, chocolate, and vanilla. Finish is a mix of sweetness and alcohol burn, lingering for some time. This one is still a little raw but I can see it developing over the next few years into something amazing. I need to grab a bottle of this one as soon as I can.

M - Heavy body and flavor with moderate carbonation. It was pretty thin at the beginning but it really developed once it warmed up into a rich, creamy, feel with plenty of lingering sweet heat in the finish.

O - Very good beer. It is still pretty hot at the moment but it is still a very easy drinking barrel aged barleywine. I am really glad I made the long trek down to Capone¬ís to try it.

(22oz bottle thanks to Jyoungsbcp) deep ruby brown with ring of tan bubbles but sparse. Alcohol coating the glass like none other.  Nose of rich caramel, vanilla, raisin, subtle bourbon, Complex and decadent. Taste is a bit alcoholic, vanilla, toasty, subtle chocolate, bourbon. Great linger. Excellent!

Draft @ RFD, Washington DC. Pours a dark ruby almsot black color with a small off-white head. Has a sweetish malty caramel and dark fruit aroma with hoppy hints. Sweetish malty hoppy dark fruit and caramel flavor with weak hints of bourbon. Has a sweetish malty hoppy bitter slightly woody caramel and dark fruit finish.

2011 bottle shared by badnewsbeers. Ruddy, sediment laden deep orange-brown body, thin ring of beige carbonation. Nose of caramel, brown sugar, and alcohol. Boozy body with big alcohol notes, brown sugar, and caramel; sweet, bitter, and warming. Potent and very good.

Well my rating just got erased by my phone so my review is going to suck. This was really complex and tasty. The bourbon barrel is very outstanding. Nice vanilla finish. Sweet and rich and thick on the palate. Very nice beer here.
2011. bottle. dark reddish brown, ruby almost with minimal head. aroma of caramelized sugar, anise, and alcohol. flavor of maple syrup, bourbon, vanilla, caramel, and booze...

Served on draft at Beer Run in Charlottesville, VA on 5/19/11. Pours a clear copper color with a medium sized creamy tan head. Decent head retention and lacing. Aroma of bourbon, caramel, toffee, toasted wood, coconut and a bitter hop finish. The taste is bourbon, toffee, caramel, toasted malts and a bitter hop finish. Medium bodied with some warming alcohol notes. Nice.

Courtesy of northernbrews 
Bottle:  The aroma consists of caramel, light fruit, banana bread, and a touch of vanilla.  It pours a dark reddish-brown with a one finger khaki head.  The flavor starts with lots of caramel, toffee, and light banana bread.  The finish has muted citrus notes, vanilla, and a touch of bourbon. Thanks Paul for sharing.  Bottle pours caramel color with off white head.  Aroma is caramel and bourbon.  Medium to heavy mouthfeel.  Flavor is well balanced between the caramel and booze.  A touch hot.  But a great beer overall.

Shared by turd. Pours a dark ruddy brown with one finger of sandstone head. Rich bourbony nose, very dextrinous with lots of vanilla and wood with caramel and raisiny notes in the background. Flavor is rich and raisiny with some caramel and tannic wood. Very full and velvety palate with a spicy alcoholic note.

Bottle from a trade with daknole.  Thanks Dakine.    Pours dark brown with a thin mocha head.  Nose is sweet bourbon, vanilla, oak.  Flavor is sweet, heat isn¬ít all too noticeable, some more oak,  brown sugar, tobacco.  Body seems a little thin for such a big beer.  Certainly not a bad beer, but it seems kind of one-dimensional.

Bought for me by a guy names Chip @ Waldo¬ís Pizza in KC .. . Pours a deep burnt caramel brown .. . this was wonderful- from molasses, caramel, pastry, fudge, and dark minced fruits .. . sticky mouthfeel and smooth- great now and will be great in ten years .. . i loved every drop! .. . he¬ís got stupid cool hiphop style!!

Bourbon nose with some sweetness, cotton candy, and stuff.  No lasting head, brown head.  Sweet cotton candy, bourbon sweetness, sharp grassy hoppiness...sweet dessertish, lightly boozy but sweetness and hoppiness of the underlying beer overshadows the bourbon influence..some pineyness...just a little overwhelming with the strong influence of everything going on.

On tap at beachwood. red/dark brown with thin biege head. Big bourbon nose with vanilla and oak, some plum, milk chocolate and prune undertones. Very smooth, well carbonated, full bodied, but the bourbon and booze is too strong with a harsh bite, needs some age to mellow and balance out. However still a very good beer and worth seeking out.

Bottle thanks to Bleeg, shared at the May tasting. Pours a dark ruby with a small off white head that diminishes quickly to nothing. The aroma is vanilla, oak, and smoke. Thick mouthfeel with a vanilla malt flavor with the alcohol present but not overpowering. Enjoyed this barley wine from Firestone.

Pours dark amber with notes of dried fruits (think plum and raisin).  The palate shows off the abv but also give serious depth to the bourbon and vanilla flavors from the char of the barrel.  You get some deep fruit hints here as well such as plums and dried figs.

Bottle shared by Dan.  Clear, very dark brown pour and an aroma of plums, raisins and booze.  Flavor is very spicey, boozy prunes, and a little hops along with a hot alcohol aftertaste.  Still hot as a young beer, but can only get better with age.

22oz bottle shared by doug, thanks 
Appearance: Clear dark mahogany with a medium sized beige head and some lacing 
Aroma: Bourbon, woody, cherries and sweet caramel 
Taste: Bourbon, vanilla, woody and some hot alcohols, dry finish 
A great barley wine, loved every drop.

Bomber. Pours a dark brown color with some reddish hints and a nice large thick white head. The aroma is massive sweet bourbon; vanilla, toffee, even a bit of the cherries from red wine barrels. The flavor is amazing; super sweet vanilla, oak, brown sugar, toffee, caramel, lots of heat, dark sour cherries, earthy and very dry. Superb.

No head left; deep brown cola-coloured beer. Dried wood, liquorice, and a touch of pine, ever so slightly smokey. Alcohol already present in the nose. Vanilla, smoked, with the vanilla(beans) returning retronasal with a vengeance. Obvious Bourbon casks, and fruity, estery hints. Very rich, alcoholwarming and a little (welcome) bite in the finish. Superb Barley Wine, especially in the finish.  Many thanks to Evan & Matt!

Bottle, big thanks to Boody for finally getting to this one.  Aroma has nice rich notes of toffee, dark fruit, vanilla, slight chocolate, bourbon, rum soaked bread, some slight red fruit.  A bouquet of flavors start with sweet chocolate, coffee and some cocoa powder, leads into dark fruit, vanilla and bourbon notes, lots of roasted malt with a delicious dry bitter and slightly sweet finish. Sampled at SIB. Pours a ruby red/brown with fine lacing. Aroma is of dark fruits, caramel, and bourbon. Flavour reflects this, highlighting the bourbon as the main characteristic.Really sweet to begin with, but very well balanced with a woody after taste. Lovely.

5/12/2011 in bottle poured into chalice. there was a lot going on in this beer. hints of tobacco, dark chocolate, and Bourbon.  will be drinking again when wallet allows.

Damn tasty all the way around!

Moderately transparent ruddy-mahogany body with a bit of a smallish off-white head.  Decent legging.  Starts fairly sweet with some brown sugar flavors, before some bourbon takes over in the middle.  Tobacco, some roastiness also follow.  There is also a dry woody, barrel character.  This finishes a bit boozy and somewhat ethanolic.  A little harsh around the edges, but still really tasty beer.  Not quite in the class of Bourbon Old Stock.

Bottle from Bleeng. Thanks!Pours a deep, dark, and sexy black with a nose of gently aged bourbon and oak, roasted sweet chocolate, and a touch of pipe tobacco.  Flavor follows suit but the bourbon and oak is deeper and a tad musty.  Thick and chewy on the tongue.  Awesome beer.

oured from a bottle at Hoffer¬ís Cigar Bar

text: Bottle. 22 oz. Split with Sean and Vinnie on Memorial Day. Courtesy of Vinnie. Pours a dark bloody ruby maroon with a two-finger off-white head. Lacing is minimal, and after awhile, it dissipates and leaves a clean, flat surface. Almost chewy and yet very juicy. Finishes with a slight burn and bit of roasty cocoa flavor. Very nice barley wine, but this tastes much more like an American strong ale.

In typical Firestone fashion, this beer does barrel-aging the right way.  Just the right amount of sweet, hot bourbon to blend well with rich malt sweetness and a totally subdued hop character that doesn¬ít create a harsh, overly bitter finish.  Manages to be rich and velvety without cloying sweetness.  Darn impressive, and I¬ím not big on BA Barley Wines (why is Wooden Hell my number one want, again?).
Another one that I couldn¬ít identify who brung the thing, regardless, danka.  This was  a pleasant surprise.  Get sum.

On tap at Capone¬ís, Norristown. Lucky to have been in town when the Firestone event was going down, and thanks to Matt and Craig for saving me some samples! Very fine pour, ruby-to-mahogany spectrum, with a thin but fine and frothy head that lingers, leaving nice retention. Body appears to be a bit oily, but not at the expense of appropriate carbonation. Nose is powerful, with heavy bourbon the dominant element but with notable vanilla, mild fruit, toffee, a hint of molasses perhaps, like a complex liqueur. Body is quite full, not from carbonation but from sheer substance. Flavors are as complex as the nose, with wood, sherry, vanilla, and very intensely combined and integrated malts all coming together like a port that has elements of a mildly hoppy strong ale or old ale. Really a terrific beer, but the only knock for me was that the bourbon was too promiment throughout for my tastes. Even so, an easy 4.

Bottle¬Ö Hazy, dark, mahogany ale with a small, creamy, light brown head. The aroma is a rich, decadent m√©lange of white oak, bourbon, caramel, vanilla and coconut. Full-bodied with a milky mouthfeel and modest carbonation. The flavor mirrors the aroma in that it is a delicious marriage of caramel, toffee, vanilla, coconut and oak. Malty, rich, warming finish. Kudos to dosbeerigos for sharing his bottle of this elixir!

Big thanks to dcschiller for hooking this one up.  Pours a brown with red highlights and a tan head that recedes.  Nose is the definition of depth and complexity: caramel, toffee, booze, bourbon, vanilla, wood, some candied coconut, slight cherries, and some joy also.  Flavor is similarly wondrous: this one manages to tread the line of too bourbony very well, like a gymnast walking over croc-infested waters.  Flavor gives notes of wood, brandy, bourbon, cherry, marshmallow, vanilla, toffee, and a big alcohol presence that is not unexpected, but shows in the wild, long legs.  Light to medium in body and every bit of 10% alcohol.  A thing of beauty!

Bomber shared by bleeng at the May Houston RB tasting.  Pours dark brown with tan bubbles in lieu of head.  Nose is of rich caramel, toffee and vanilla with alcohol noticeable.  Taste is fantastic with bourbon, chocolate and coconut like a candy bar.  Mouthfeel was thick and chewy.  Very nice.

Aroma:I really like the aroma. It smells of caramel, sweet malts, dark fruits like figs, and a little bourbon.

Appearance:Pours a deep mahogany color. Nice head, but quickly dissipates. Great lacing.

Overall:I really enjoyed this beer, it¬ís really well balanced, and a great sipper. It reminds me a lot of sipping on a nice bourbon. I believe this one should age really well.

Thanks to bleeng for bringing this beer from Alabama. Pours a keep reddish brown with small head. Nose of whiskey, coconut, toffee, vanilla....gorgeous. Flavors are right on with aroma profile, with added bourbon for good flavor...this is very, very nice. A little bit of heat, but still pretty well integrated. Love this beer.
Bottle. Dark brown with no head.  Caramel and dark fruit aromas.  Caramel, dark fruit, brown sugar, vanilla flavors.  So much going on here, and it¬ís all GOOD..........

A wonderful beer. ours a dark brown with a thin tan head. The aroma is oak, bourbon, vanilla, caramel among others. The flavor is at first bourbon and vanilla. Then you get the caramel. Some oak and booze soon arrive. Made for sipping, this is just a damn good beer.

Bomber from the Burger Bar in Mandalay Bay.  What a find.  Dark brown pour with a no head.  Lots of sweet bourbon up front in the aromas, caramel added some more sweetness. Bottle.... Clear dark brown pour ,   small ,wispy beige head , some lace . Malty aroma with notes of caramel, chocolate , vanilla and bourbon . Rich malt flavor , chocolate , vanilla , bourbon , oak , tobacco and some dark fruit . Full bodied , sweet but not cloying . Strong alcohol presense but not in a bad way, it works well .
