Served from a 22 oz bottle from OTM. The appearance is a deep amber hue with a very clear body. The aromas are creamy vanilla, silky smooth bourbon, and some fruity booze. The flavors are strong with the vanilla bean, some sweet bread, and bourbon with a touch of french oak. There is a booziness to it at times that isn¬ít bad but could use some rounding. The mouth is really smooth. Great brew. Keep them coming Firestone.

Thanks Dan!  Pours the darkest shade of ruby, with a quickly fading tan head.  Aroma of canned pineapple, coconut, and honey.  Tastes of dark chocolate, vanilla, coconut, and fruit cocktail.  Smooth and viscous with just the right amount of alcohol warmth.  I think I¬íve found a new favorite barley wine.
Pours a very dark brown almost black color with a very thin head. Has a caramel, vanilla and light booze smell. Has a vanilla, chocolate, coconut and booze all in the taste. Very nicely done!

Sampled on 2/19/2011 on tap at Beer Revolution. This barley wine pours an eclipse black to dark brown color from the tap. Small to medium sized white foamy head. The aroma is dark fruit, raisins, caramel, wood and bourbon. A medium to full bodied barley wine. The malts are dark fruit, raisins, wood, and tobacco. The hops are herbal and earthy. Very nice balanced barley wine, with big malt flavors, with a touch of wood and a whole lot of bourbon. Very nice barley wine. Great sipping beer. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is slightly sweet.
Good barley wine, Very grainy, what you would expect to find in a typical barley wine, nothing really standed out too much. But it was a really good example of the style. Would have again
Bottle at Dark Lord Day. Thanks for the share. Poured light brown with little head. Taste is of alcohol, light spices and dark fruits. Overall really well rounded and balanced. Would have again.
Bottle at CL Rosso Batch 3 Release. Pours clear brown. Aroma is oaky, roasted malt, spice, wood. Taste is caramel and dark fruit. Very tasty.

Serving: On tap at Fireworks.  It pours black with a small, creamy, tan head.  The nose is lots of bourbon, wood, and sherry.  The flavor pulls those notes together with an almost creamy mouthfeel.  The bourbon stays strong with some almost dark cherry cola notes underneath.  Rich in body with lower carbonation leading to a medium crown and coke finish.  Different and tasty.
Boozy with notes of dates, chocolate dusting, Bourbon & strong coffee. Strong and chock full of alcohol. The stone fruits and chocolate really mesh well. Slick and oily feel.

22 oz bottle provided by jtclockwork, thanks James. Poured an orange/brown body with a slightly foamy small head. Aroma of alcohol, honey, molasses, wet bread and sugar. Great smooth body with medium carbonatoin and a light syrupy feel. Flavor of liquid caramel, toffee, alcohol, honey, vanilla and some wood. really nice stuff, FW rocks and is a welcome addition to the NJ beer scene.

Bottle from thome50 via a trade.  Drinking this while at a conference for math educators with some other nerds.  Pour is cola brown with a nice khaki head head.  Sweet aroma.  Some vanilla, brown sugar, raisins, and some booze.  Complex flavors.  Sweet with vanilla, raisins, figs, touch of chocolate, and some booze towards the finish.  Slight oak presence in the finish.  Probably one of the best, if not the best barley wine I¬íve had.  Definitely looking forward to seeing what happens to this beer with some time on it.  Thanks once again Justin!

UPDATED: JUN 2, 2011 Bottle at Fountainhead thanks to a kind soul. Pours a slightly murky brown with a small off-white head. nose is figs and raisins, some vanilla and earthy oak notes. The oak is very well integrated. On taste, very soft and minimal boozy components. More dried fruit and raisins again with well integrated oak, light vanilla and light tannin character. Fantastic stuff and an excellent example of great barrel aging.
Bomber at Justin¬ís.   Pours a lovely brown-black, minimal lacey foam.  Aroma is straight cinnamon and booze.  Flavor is amazingly silky and the ABV is crazy well-hidden.  Amazing brew.

650ml bottle split with McBerko. Pours a ruby brown with almost no head. Gorgeous aroma, mixed dried fruit, some wood. Amazing taste of aged fruit, caramel malt but not too sweet, booze is very well worked. Fantastic!

Bottle, big thanks to Jtclockwork for sharing this at Dmac¬ís. Pours out a somewhat clear ruby hued brown color with a small lacing head. Aroma is of nice vanilla, oak, and slight alcohol. Taste is very complex with notes of vanilla, oak, tobacco, and a lingering sweetness in there also. Slight tell of the alcohol on the finish, but it is very well hidden. Up there for the beer of the night. Very well done.

22 oz. bottle, courtesy of Glouglouburp (thanks Dany), split with manuchampions, pours dark mahogany with a small beige head. Aroma of bourbon barrels, dark fruits, caramel and brown sugar. Flavour is very liqueur-like, with notes of sherry, port, caramel, brown sugar and sweetness. Very well-balanced with the sweetness just hit right. ABV is incredibly well-worked in. Outstanding.

Bottle from a generous trader. Shared by me at Dmac¬ís tasting. Pours dark brown. Tan head. Nose/taste of bourbon barrel, wood, dates, fig, toffee, caramel and raisin. Some alcohol in finish. Full mouth feel.

On tap as a guest draft at Dark Lord Day 2009.

A: Fairly dark--especially for the style. Some reddish highlights with a light, cream-colored head.

S: Oak, roasted malt, chocolate, and bits of vanilla. The oak definitely came through, as I had this not too longer after sampling the Oak Aged DL.

T: Fairly-roasted malt with some caramel/toffee taste as well as a certain earthiness to the underlying malt. On top of this lies some of the oak/wood flavors as well as characteristics of chocolate and hints of vanilla. A bit of bourbon in there, too.

M: Very chewy and quite heavy. Fairly low carbonation.

D: Quite drinkable, as the alcohol is hidden, but not too much.

Serving type: on-tap

Reviewed on: 05-01-2009
From a tap,dark red,vanilla,tobacco,hint of of dark cherry,a little boozey taste.I like it.

On tap at Cloverleaf.  What a BW.  Pours a dark murky brown color with a caramel colored head.  Has an aroma of bourbon, dark fruit, caramel, and perhaps some earthiness.  Has a sweet dark fruit taste with notes of caramel and chocolate.  A nice hop layer.  Creamy mouthfeel.  Excellent.

Another FW bottle courtesy of Richie.

Pours deep, deep copper, darker than most barleywines, with a thin tan head that recedes slowly to small collar and some sticky legs on the sides.

Aroma is spectacular, everything I¬íd want in a BB barleywine.  There is the deep, sweet caramel malts, toffee, vanilla and hints of hops, though this seems closer to an English BW than American.  The bourbon is perfectly balanced in the nose, sweet vanilla, light wood notes and bourbon.  Wow.

The taste is almost as good with smooth bourbon and vanilla up front, meshing perfectly with the sugary malts, toffee and caramel underneath.  Nice alcohol burn in the finish, just tingling the tongue.

The mouthfeel is super smooth and medium bodied with lots of barrel character and soft carbonation.

This is a fantastic BA barleywine, one of the best I¬íve had in a long time.  FW certainly knows their way around barrel aging.  World class.

Beatiful boxed bomber from Capone¬ís.  Pours into my Stone RIS snifter turbid mahogany/chestnut, with 1-finger clingy off-white head.  Nose is heavy bourbon, oak, figgy fruit, cherry, blackberry, port.  Gorgeous nose here.  The flavor is on the sweet side initially, with a huge bourbon and oaky element, and tons of fruity notes of the blackberry and port wine variety, brown sugar, backup hops.  as it warms, the sweetness goes away somewhat, and the oaky bourbon mixed with the port and blackberry emerges, plus backup hops and caramel notes, and some finishing rauchy and cognacy notes.  Amazingly complex and with very well hidden alcohol, this is a beer for the ages, one of the finest beers I have ever quaffed, and a truly earth-shattering experience.  As usual with these big beers, I need to remind lightweights and barleywine haters to leave this beer to those who can appreciate and understand it, while you go back to your parent¬ís basement for a sixer of the new Miller Light with the corkscrew bottles..

on tap at Capone¬ís served in a tulip pour was dark mahogany with one finger of tan head that dissipated rather quickly but did leave a nice ring of lacing around the glass. nose was bourbon,oak vanilla and malts. taste was bourbon,oak,chocolate,coconut,coffee,malts and a beautiful hint of cherries in the Finnish. wow what a brew definitely one of the better barley wines I have ever had. hats off to Firestone on this brew

On tap at Capone¬ís. Poured a dark brown color with a smaller sized off white head. Aromas of vanilla, bourbon, dark fruits, wood, and caramel. Tastes of bourbon, vanilla, dark fruits, wood, caramel, and some nuttiness.

Draft at Monk¬ís Cafe.

Pours a deep dark copper/chestnut color with dark ruby/mahogany edges and a one finger frothy off-white head that quickly settles into a thin lasting ring. Sporadic small spots of lacing left behind.

Amazing complex nose with a blend of earthy oak, luscious vanilla, sweet boozy bourbon, dark fruit and earthy/leathery malt. The barrel character is very prominent with lots of toasted oak without smelling burnt. Sweet bourbon and lots of vanilla and marshmallow mellowing things out. As it warms the malts become more prominent with hints of leather, toffee, hazelnut and caramel. Slightly vinous with hints of cherry, grape and plum. Smells amazing and the bourbon is well integrated in the nose without overpowering the other elements.

Medium bodied with the perfect balance of earthy barrel character, boozy bourbon, sweet malt and alcohol heat. Very similar to the aroma with a prominent barrel presence up front. Earthy oak that is slightly toasted with sweet bourbon flavor that is prominent but not overly hot. Although the bourbon flavor is strong, it¬ís not overpowering and the other flavors are able to stand out. There are also notes of vanilla and toasted coconut from the barrel, mellowing things out. Slightly hot with some nice burning warmth in the finish but the ABV is pretty well masked at 13%. Underneath there is a nice blend of earthy/leathery and sweet malt flavor. Slightly earthy barleywine flavor with hints of sweet caramel toffee, rye and faint cocoa. Vinous with dark fruit flavor, especially dark cherry as well as some grape, plum, raisin and fig. More heat toward the end of the swallow but this beer is excellently balanced, delicious and dangerously drinkable. One of the best barrel aged beers I¬íve ever had. Amazing!

22 oz bottle.  2011 release.  Pours a cola brown with a very small light tan head that leaves small spots of lacing around the glass.  The aroma is wonderful.  Caramel, toasted coconut, light oxidation, vanilla, brandy (not sure if any of this was brandy barrel aged, but I get it in the aroma), some light cherry notes, a decent amount of bourbon, some light alcohol, a light leather note, and a bit of oak.  The barrels certainly come through in the aroma.   The initial taste is sweet with caramel, brown sugar, coconut, and vanilla.  Then a little brandy and a light oxidation comes through as well.  Bourbon and a bit of leather on the finish with a light bitterness.  A light alcohol heat, but much less than you would expect for a 13% beer.  Medium-heavy body.  Very smooth mouthfeel.  Manages to be sweet without being syrupy.  Low carbonation works very well for the beer.  Overall, a great beer.  Probably the best barley wine I have had so far.  The barrels certainly dominate the nose and taste, which I quite enjoy.  I found myself not wanting to finish my glass just so I could continue to enjoy the aroma for a few extra minutes.

Lightly hazy, brown burgundy color with a small, off white head that left nice lacing on the glass.  Aroma of vanilla, wine, light bourbon, dark fruits, caramel, and light alcohol.  Taste of dark fruits, caramel malts, nuts, vanilla, wood, smoke, wine, and light alcohol in the finish.
Hands down the best BW I¬íve had. At least a dozen complex flavors and aromas going on here. Dominated by raisin, chocolate, vanilla and bourbon. Epic. Chewy thick.
Mini growler.  Pours a deepbrown with amber notes.  Aroma of tobacco, vanilla, oak, light hop notes, caramel and dark fruits.  Flavor of bourbon, vanilla, oak, dark fruits, caramel and toffee.

Bottle.  Pours a very deep dark reddish brown, with thin beige head.  The aroma on this is amazing, oak, vanilla, cherry, and even a touch of caramel. Taste is extremely complex, very oaky start with tons of ripe dark fruits like raisins, figs, and plums, rounds out in the middle with a piney hops kick, finishes out long, with a fair amount of alcohol heat, even has a touch of sourness as is lingers.  Very sticky and thick, almost chewy.  this is absolutely fantastic, I bought 2 bottles planning on aging one but had to pop open the second.  Hopefully my store has another!

UPDATED: FEB 19, 2012 April 9th 2011.  Had this on a cold night, perfect conditions.  Wow!  Burbon nose but not overpowering.  Alcohol burn the whole time, (love it).  Very chewy.  Burbon vanilla and a hint of cherry.  Well balanced and smooth.  Just enough hops to support the malt so that it wasn¬ít too sweet or cloying.  A very well balanced beer.  This makes me a barley wine fan again.  Feb 19th 2012.  Had to raise the rating a little.  Still the best.
A very strong molasses and alcohol aroma. Looks nice. Tons of molasses/honey/caramel flavors in this. A sweetness throughout. A bit sugary at the end. Unfortunately very pricey. Good stuff though.
Color is ruby red and dark, some lacing and low carbonation. Aroma is sweet, bourbon and some fruitiness. Sweet taste, not dry and good liquor character. Very good all around.

4/2/11. Bomber thanks to dcschiller! Solid brown pour with a small tan head that fades to a ring fast but sticks. Relatively mild aroma of oak, vanilla, dark fruits, and a hint of metal. Sweet malty and fruity flavor with touches of tobacco and earthy leaves. I was hoping for more barrel character. Not bad.

Tap @ Bailey¬ís Taproom...  Poured near opaque, deep brown with a light, tan head.  Nose had buttercorn, molasses, toffee, and butternut squash.  Decent carbonation, a little fizzy on the tongue.  Full bodied, very malty and the alcohol tones played like bourbon whiskey and toasted oak. Buttery toffee (not diacetyl!), like burnt sugar and caramel.  Dark fruits like figs, dates, raisins, prunes and hints of honey sweetness.  A little bit floralness crept in to balance the sweetness and a big malted grain finish.  As it warmed the whiskey notes really became more evident.

On tap at Bailey¬ís Taproom

Poured into a snifter with virtually no head.  Color is a dark murky brown, with some red showing when light shines through it.

Aroma hits you first with caramel and toffee, then vanilla, bourbon, and a hint of prunes.

On the front of the tongue this tastes like candy, then there¬ís chocolate further back in the mouth and cherry in the finish.  This is very, very smooth and not at all cloying.  It should be sipped slowly, but it¬ís hard not to drink it faster than an 13% beer ought to be.
Draft.  Medium beige head, garnet-black body.  Aroma is moderately sweet, Bourbon, some smoke, chocolate, wood.  Taste is moderately sweet, Bourbon, some wood, vanilla.  Sticky medium-full body.

pours a dark brown, not glass or shine to it, a little ugly, a light beige head, good retention and lacing... the aroma is decent, not as good as I as expecting, can¬ít really tell it was barrel-aged at all, molasses mostly, a hint of hops... again can¬ít really tell this is barrel-aged, a little bourbon, lots of chocolate, caramel, and vanilla, hoppy bourbon finish... good not the greatness I was expecting

12oz pours at Black Squirrel in DC.  Pours a translucent, deep brown with very little off white head.  Nose is boozy, bourbon, vanilla, almost like Johnnie Walker, raisins, oranges, dried fruit, coconut.  Flavor is sweet, brown sugar, malty, orange, boozy, rum, whiskey, vanilla, cracker crumbs, a little cookie dough.  Full bodied, boozy, sweet, hot finish.  Pretty good, a touch too boozy, probably would have been better at 10% and not 12%.

Glowing caramel pour with a slight fizzy head.  Aroma is fruity, very boozy, some bourbon, vanilla, chocolate, dried fruits abound.  Mouth feel is slick, oily.  Very hot, but loads of dried fruits and bourbon in the flavor, very refined. Tasty but very boozy, we will see what time does to this guy.  Excellent

UPDATED: APR 4, 2011 Incredible barleywine with beautiful dark chocolate, cognac, pitted fruit and unpitted fruit skins, tobacco, leather, subtle bourbon (well integrated) cardamom, clove, and surprisingly dryish in the remarkably lengthy finish. Impeccable balance from sniff to aftertaste.

Simply one of the most amazingly sophisticated barleywines I¬íve ever tasted.

In another six months when the heat has subsided, this will be a true masterpiece.

Edit: After only a few days resting, the heat has almost totally vanished, the carbonation is softer, and the flavors are already more married.

Kudos, Firestone!

22oz bottle, courtesy dcschiller and drowland,  pours with a slight tan head. Oaky aroma, slight bit of bourbon. Very bourbon taste, a bit one dimensional. Oak and bourbon dominate. Alright, a bit overhyped.
Tap at the double windsor. Strong yet smooth with a big hoppy bourbon and oak aroma. Its combined with hints of chocolate, deep rish finish. Very complex. Vert good

Pours deep brown into a snifter. Off-white head with excellent retention recedes to hug rim. Pit fruit, vanilla and oak aromas. Sweet coconut and almonds upfront turning hot and boozy in the lasting dark caramel covered pit fruit and oak finish.

On tap at JJ Brewsky¬ís in Camarillo.  Deep, dark, amber color with a creamy head.  The aromas are never ending on this one, with strong burnt caramel, raisin, and definite bourbon whiskey overtones.  On the palate there is a beautiful balance of raisin, toffee, toasted vanilla, rum cake, and an underlying hoppiness that is persitent, but never overpowers.  Excellent barleywine and a great addition to an increasinly inspired lineup!

On tap at American Craft in Brookline. Deep dark brown body with a thin brown head. Nose is sweet, brown sugar, caramel, and traces of vanilla. Amazing and subdued barrel notes with lots of rich tobacco. The sweet and chewy chocolate malts have some nice toffee notes to go along with the dark chocolate bitters. Very heavy palate but reasonably lively carbonation keep this from really slowing me down.

(22oz bottle).  Pours mahogany color with minimal head.  Aroma of bourbon, oak, vanilla and caramel. Taste is sweet with loads of vanilla and bourbon.  Medium to full bodied with a creamy/slick texture. Smooth finish.  Delicious beer!

Tap at itap.  Pour is darker than most barleywines.  It¬ís deep dark brown with a thin ring of tan foam.  Aroma is amazing. Loaded with toffee malt, caramel, vanilla, molasses, coconut, faint chocolate, and light spicy notes.  Thankfully, the flavor is very true to the aroma with loads of toffee malt, caramel, vanilla, light coconut, faint tobacco, and a light fruitiness. Alcohol is almost non-existent. This is really exceptional.  I had to have 2.

Aroma is very complex and the initial smell is more that of good bourbon than beer. It is followed by a leathery, tobacco smell that fades of to that of a slight bitterness. The appearance is a darker amber/red color with a khaki head. The taste is just as complex as the aroma. The initial taste is sweet bourbon that is followed by a slight bitterness that is quickly beaten into submission by the malt flavor. Great beer with not too much bourbon flavor

Draft served in a snifter at The Bridge. Pours a deep, brownish mahogany-amber color with a tiny off-white head. The barrel notes are really nicely balanced with a big slate of rich, dark fruits- notes of bourbon, vanilla, caramel, oak, plums, berries, brown sugar, and chocolate. Flavor of raisins, brown sugar, vanilla, caramel, plums, chocolate, bourbon, and earthy hops. Full-bodied, with modest carbonation, and a smooth, rich, coating mouthfeel that¬ís nice to savor. Excellent sipper, a bourbon barrel barleywine that does everything it should.

Bottle pours deep brown with traces of red and a khaki head.  Aroma shows notes of milk chocolate, cocoa powder, caramel, bourbon and cherry. Flavor shows the same with additional notes of toasted coconut, 
tobacco, oak, vanilla, more bourbon, and brown sugar.  Overall body is moderate to full and finishes with a touch of warming alcohol.  This beer has definately taken on quite a bit of the barrel and is fairly well balanced as it is.  However, i think a few months from now some of the naked alc will integrate and this is going to be amazing!!

Slight initial head fading to a ring of foam hugging the glass.  Deep, transparent dark red color.  Aroma is a rich and cohesive chewy marshmallow, coconut, vanilla, polished bourbon, soft oak, and a touch of raisin/date barley wine underneath.  Holy hell there is a lot going on with this beer!  Dark cherry and tobacco in the flavor with thick and raw bourbon, vanilla, and a fairly tight barley wine malt profile.  Thick and decadent feel in the mouth.  Prickly alcohol lingers with the bourbon/barley wine notes after each sip.  No doubt about it this is a big, ass kicking beer but Firestone pulls it off with a smooth and complex presentation.  Absolute stunner.

22 oz. bottle from Full Throttle Bottles. This had a fluffy head, for about two seconds; now, it¬ís just thin and wispy. It has a dark brown body that looks wonderful. This smells great. It smells of strong vanilla, coconut, chocolate, and sweet bourbon. This has a very pungent aroma that is very pleasing. Lots of sweet coconut at first. After the coconut, I¬ím getting a light caramel, sugar, vanilla, coconut, and bourbon flavor. It¬ís a bit hot; that¬ís to be expected. This has a very rich texture this is quite viscous, relative to other beers. The booze detracts from the quality. It¬ís annoyingly hot at some points. It has a lot of different dimensions. A subtle hint of oak comes through at the end. There are bits of that dark cherry coming through at the end, as the description says. This is very good, and heavily influenced by their use of barrels.

Botle: &nbsp Deep burnt brown sugar, brownish of sorts, dark burnt caramel hues, thin to moderate off-white head, foamy, sparce lacing. &nbsp Huge graham cracker aroma, bourbon, vanilla, and just overall super super malty. &nbsp Some slight chocolate covered cherries, in a very alcoholic way. &nbsp The heat is very noticeable. &nbsp Yeah, this one has some heat on it. &nbsp Body and mouthfeel are fairly big. &nbsp How can it not be?! &nbsp Strong malty and biscuity finish, loads of Bourbon, vanilla, and graham cracker. &nbsp Hop profile is minor. &nbsp This is one malty example. &nbsp Oh, and this one is sweet beyond most others! &nbsp Strong bourbon and vanilla on a  bed of graham cracker. &nbsp This one isn¬ít overly hoppy, instead its a huge malty sweet bourbon and vanilla styled example. &nbsp I am finding it difficult to write about this one because it is just simply kicking my ass. &nbsp This one  breaks a lot of the rules. &nbsp Holy piss is this good!

Tap at Samuel Horne. Pours very black with a slight creamy head. Aroma is mostly malty with light darkish fruit hints. Full bodied. It is sweet with lots of dark fruit - more cherry than date. Bourbon and fruit. Could be some floral hop. Oak seems blended in.  It finishes sweet but not sticky. Liquid food. Fruit juice du jour. Lovin it.
Black with no head. Sweet chocolate molasses and candy sugar aroma and taste.

On tap at the Rose and Crown in Palo Alto (after narrowly missing a Pliny the Younger tapping... doh). Poured black with a sizable, slowly dissipating head. Smelled sweet with figs and raisins. The initial taste was similar, with notes of vanilla, bourbon, and fruit, and it finished with a surprising coconut aftertaste. Mouthfeel was thick and very smooth. This is probably the best barleywine I¬íve ever had, and I think one of the reasons I liked it was because it didn¬ít have any overwhelming hoppy bitternesss to it, nor did it have any heat from the alcohol. Delicious and well done.

On tap @ Stone. Hazy copper with a small beige head. Aroma of dates, bourbon, caramel, toffee and wood. The flavor is caramel flan, bourbon, dark fruit with some sharp wood notes. Medium to full body with mild carbonation and a long finish. Very nice malty English style Barley Wine, lots of dark fruit and the bourbon flavors are at the perfect level.

Draft at Stone at the 14th release. Medium brown/amber pour, off-white head.  Caramel malts, milk chocolate, vanilla, bourbon, and oak.  The flavors are very complex and complement well.  A very nice barleywine.

Might be one of the best beers i¬íve ever had, i¬íd quite possibly punch my mom for another drank. Huge milk chocolate flavor, no noticable heat, body was thick enough to hold the flavor, thin enough not to be cloying, somewhat one note, but depth to the chocolate flavor and roast. i¬íd say its the west coast sexual chocolate.

Sampled at 1702, Tucson; April 2010
This beer arrives from the tap with a dark, concentrated amber / brown color that shows a clear¬íish hue in the light.  It is topped by a thin, creamy textured, dark tan to amber-tinged colored head.  Bourbon aromatics jump out at me from the get-go; notes of vanillin, coconut, a hint of woody spiciness, lots of oak-wood like fresh cut plank aromas and even a touch of alcohol heat are noticeable.  The aroma is quite nice, but leaves me wondering were the aromatics from the base beer are.

The beer is sweet tasting as it first hits my mouth, with a viscous, chewy character that finishes with a hot alcohol and Bourbon spiciness that lingers on the palate; it actually does remind me of sipping on Bourbon.  There are lots of flavors reminiscent of vanilla and toasted coconut; wow, the Bourbon barrel really just completely dominates this beer.  Luckily the malt is big and sweet enough to carry all the barrel character, but you better really like Bourbon if you are going to enjoy this beer.  The base beer really plays a subservient role here.  The Barley Wine does contribute a lush texture, with caramelized malt sweetness and some toasted malt character.  The beer finishes with a really spicy, almost hot at times, peppery barrel character that lingers on the palate for quite some time.

The vanillin and coconut notes are nice in this beer and it is well accentuated by the malt sweetness, but this is too hot and too Bourbon dominated in the end.  If you really like Bourbon then I can see this being quite the enjoyable tipple, but it is perhaps a bit too much for me.

On-tap at City Beer.  Good barleywine aromas, creamy mouthfeel, A bit of creamy off-white head on brown.  Carbonation was a tad fizzy.  Decent drinkability.  A decent barleywine, though not exceptional on this day.

City Beer Store.  This was my third time drinking Abacus (past two at Toronado).  I¬ím not the biggest fan of bourbon barrel-aged barleywines, but this is an awesome beer.  It pours a deep brownish purplish murk.  Virtually no head.  Somewhat ominous.  The aroma is strong on wonderful bourbon.  It¬ís a much more delicate and complex bourbon aroma than most bourbon barrel-aged beers.  Bourbon and oak dominate a bit - not that I¬ím complaining in this particular case - but there are some wonderful malty fruit flavors lurking beneath and even some chocolate and vanilla.  The fruit notes come out even more in the flavor.  It¬ís sweet but not cloying.  It tastes of malt sugars refined by barrel-aging.  The beer is thick and warming.  Abacus is probably the best barrel-aged barleywine that I¬íve come across.  Delicious stuff.

On tap @ 1702 - This was a wonderful beer.  Pours a deep brown color with no head or lacing.  Aroma is bourbon/oak, esters, and toasted malt.  Flavor is much of the same.  Alcohol was noticeable, but not over powering.  Medium body.  A very nice sipper.

AWESOME, YA Hear me!  Pours a dark brune body with a creamy off white head, malty vinous warming.  Brandy, raisins, fig, dark fruity esters.  Salty and sweet hint of cherries and chocolate.  Light plum, vanilla, tobacco, just pure English barley wine here.  Fantastic, reminds me of the 06 Angel share, just awesome!

Had this on tap at the Hard Liver fest in Seattle last weekend. Colour... carmelized brown sugar with no head. Nose... caramel and stone fruits. Palate... fairly frothy, nicely boozy, sweetly coating, plenty of Scottish toffee, burnt sugar, dark caramel, sailor jack and Christmas cake, with a very long finish.
Draft.  Dark brown with tan head. Aroma is malty, with fruit esters, some etoh. Nice English style barleywine no hop presence, drinking nice even with moderate warming. Smooth dark fruit flavors.

Draft, Hard Liver.  Pours black with a ring of white bubbles.  Aroma is pretty intense with lots of toffee, vanilla, caramel, dark fruits, brown sugar, bourbon.  All those notes are layered together beautifully in the flavor, and there are some nice woody notes that add balance.  Finishes a little hot, moderately rich body, pretty creamy feeling.  I would consider this my favorite barley wine of the day.

On tap at Hard Liver 2010. Crazy dark pour - a bit of red showing through a really deep brown. Small head - really pretty. Nuts and fruits in an explosion of flavor in this one. Deep roasted caramel malts and bourbon/vanilla, with a great hoppy finish - almost too much on the finish - this one ends seriously bitter given how thick it is. It¬ís a bit hot, but clean. Tasty, for sure.
Sampled several times at the 2010 AZ strong beer fest.  Dark amber pour.  Oak, bourbon, hops, dark fruit, vanilla.  Fantastic!

On tap at Churchill¬ís.  No head at all.  Darker than I¬íd expect from a Barleywine.  Looked more like a porter in the glass.  Nose is rich and deep.  Booze, raisins, spice.  Taste is really good barleywine.  Sweet and spicy, vanilla oak caramel brown sugar and more dark fruit.  Yummy.

A: The pour is a dark, rich amber color with a small off-white (perhaps beige) head.

S: The nose has an incredibly rich fruitiness to it which I really was not expecting. Plenty of sugar, caramel, bourbon, vanilla and oak in the nose as well.

T: The nose gave this one a lot to live up to, and I¬ím happy to say the flavors delivered! A lot of caramel and toffee sweetness, obviously, but also some really great barrel character as well. The bourbon, vanilla, oak, and even some hop bitterness really round this beer out.

M: The body is very full with a low level of carbonation that works well here.

D: Normally you don¬ít associate barleywines with easy drinking, but this one is so smooth and delicious that it¬ís easy to keep going back for more. I can¬ít wait until this is bottled.
on draft at collins pub for the real strong ale fest. slight cherry note to the barley with a very strong and lasting alcohol aftertaste
(on tap @ the brewery)dark brown body with a brown head.aroma and flavor are an awesome blend of oak,bourbon,vanilla,cotton candy,and malts.very smotth for 13%.

Thanks to whomever brought  this to the Woodshop 5.0 tasting.

This was a nice beer. Tasty, complex, smooth. I enjoyed it.
Sample from Tim¬ís growler at Woodshop 5.0.  Deep caramel brown with a wispy beige head, nice lacing.  Deep nose of red apples, brown sugar and light booze.  Great carbonation and mouth feel.

Growler at Woodshop 5.0, courtesy of a fine gentleman named Tim who I¬íd met up at the Russian River Pliny the Younger release. Thanks, dude! Pours a dark, deep yellowish-brown color; thin, medium-bubbled off-white head with patchy lacing. Lots of coconut, brown sugar, and toasty barrel character in the aroma; beautiful coconut notes. Medium-to-full body: lots of smooth brown sugar, dark fruits, coconut and oily maltiness; smooth presence in the mouth, pleasantly integrated alcohol and a good amount of lingering sweetness. Lasting finish of brown sugar, caramel and dark fruits; nicely bitter end.

On tap at the 2010 AZ Strong Beer Festival.  One of the best at the Fest.  Pours dark opaque brown with a thin tan head.  The nose is bourbon, wood, citrus hops and brown sugar.  The taste is oaky vanilla, bourbon, tart citrus and caramel malt.  Medium semi-creamy mouthfeel.  Very good beer.

Sampled @ AZ Strong Beer Fest.  Definitely Best-in-Show!!!  Deep fudge-colored pour produced a razor thin latte head.  Aroma is aggressive and exudes bourbon, vanilla, cocoa, raisin, molasses, and oak.  Taste is incredible with tons of depth and layers of flavor.  Dark fruit, maple, toffee, bourbon, vanilla, and honey dance on the tongue.  Silky but not sticky and, although sweet, far from cloying.  Pretty incredible stuff!!!

Holy hell this was the best beer at the AZ strong beer fest.  Dark brown pour, small tan head.  Aroma is just loaded with sweet bourbon, vanilla, caramel, golden raisins and wood.  Flavor is sweet but not cloying.  Vanilla and bourbon stand out and combine with raisins, toffee, wood, dark dried fruit...my goodness this stuff is amazing.

From tap at Toronado, Barley Wine Fest.  Pours clean dark brown with a small creamy and tan head. Liqourice, molasses and solid caramel malt flavours. Sweet yet not sticky. Dark malty note slowly lingering into the finish. Dark caramelish lasting impression.

sampled at az strong beer festival. Pours a deep brown with a small tan head. Aroma is bourbon, raisins, caramel, malt, hops. Flavor is chewy raisins, caramel, bourbon, molasses, oak.  Nice BA Barleywine.

Cask Stillage from the Jug at the GABF, Colorado Convention Center 26/09/2009
Big bourbon aroma. Mid brown coloured sweet and rich on the palate. Strong in alcohol with a little dryness in a very bitter chocolate malt finish.

Sample at GABF 2009. Pours a dark amber color with off-white head. Aroma is sweet and malty with notes of chocolate, ripe dark fruit, light toffee and molasses. Flavor is about the same. Medium body with a pleasing malty and boozy finish.

On tap at Monks Kettle. This dark brown ale poured with a thin bubbly tan head and a dark fruit aroma. There is a hearty malt flavor with chocolate, coffee and raisin. It starts sweet then turns pleasantly bitter. A very nice brew.

Sampled at GABF.  Murky brown pour with a bit of tan head.  Strong, sweet aroma of caramel, toffee, raisins, oak.  Flavor is vinous and thick.  An orgy of vanilla, maple syrup, oak.  Chewy palate, like you want in a huge barley wine.  Really impressive.

(Draught) Pours a murky dark brown body with a small beige head.  Aroma of roasted malt, caramel, toffee, oak, chocolate, and vanilla.  Flavor of vanilla, maple, caramel, toffee, bourbon, and chocolate with some oak in the finish.  This is Heavenly!

UPDATED: SEP 29, 2012 2012 vintage bomber. pours a deep red / brown with a nice 1+ finger off white head.  sweet nose with bourbon, oak, vanilla, and dark fruits.  med body with a very smooth balance between the barrel notes and the malts. sweet caramel malts, dark fruits play off the lingering bourbon and oak notes from the wood.  sweet dark fruit finish with some heat and a touch of citrus. this is one of the best beers around. worth every penny.

sample from the pitcher at GABF on 9/26/09...  pours a dark brown... lots of wood on the nose... big smooth body with dark fruit notes blended with a perfect level of oak.  really nice Barley Wine...

GABF Saturday.  I had tried this before, but was not able to rate it.  Pours dark dark brown, with a wispy chocolate head.  Menacingly dark, even for a Barley Wine.  Rich dark fruit and raisin on the nose, with similar flavors plus chocolate in the body.  Very well rounded, despite the intensity of it all.  I enjoyed every drop of this, and have to say that Abacus is a better ¬ìextreme¬î beer than Parabola (Barrel-aged RIS).

GABF2009 - unlike the Parabola, this one is a lot more smoothed out by the oak - it¬ís still sticky and boozy, but the rough edges are much more rounded out - a lot of dark fruit, bourbon, vanilla, toasted oak, coconut - creamy in the mouth, despite its strength - barrel aging might be overdone these days, but this one turned out nice.

Had this brew at GABF on 9/24/09.  Color is a muddy brown with light carbonation and small head.  Aroma is rich with a little oak coming out.  This is a full bodied brew with a rich feel and a finish of raisins and plums with oak and vanilla on the end.  Overall its a very good Barley Wine.

UPDATED: MAR 23, 2011 Draft at the Firestone Walker booth GABF2009. Nose of bourbon, prunes, toffee, and oaky vanilla notes. Black with a small cinnamon tan head. Flavor is bourbon and oak with dark fruits and caramel. Reminds me of FW 10 in some ways. 8/4/9/4/17 4.2 9/27/09
2011 bomber from GM Liquors. Nose is toffee, dates, vanilla, and oak. Clear brown with a medium tan head. Flavor is oaky vanilla, light sweetness, raisin pie, and a hint of alcohol warmth. Very smooth!

Tap at Toronado 22nd Anniversary.  Dark brown color with purplish hues and a small off-white head.  Aroma is sweet malt, oak, roast, bourbon, and dark fruits.  Flavor is caramel malt, roasted malt, bourbon, plum, fig, raisin, vanilla, oak, and alcohol.  Really complex and good.  Palate creamy with low carbonation.

On tap at Blue Palms. Pours a deep brown body and a small  tan ring. Aroma of wood, raisin, toffee and bourbon. Kind of a light aroma. Taste, dark fruits, vanilla, light oxidation. A bit of bourbon in the back. Well hidden alcohol. Viscous mouth, with light carbonation. Nice.

6/18/09 on draft at the Nhc. Aroma is all plum flavored alcohol without any harshness and lots of caramel. Appearance is hazy dark brown with a medium maintained cream colored head. Flavor is more rich syrupy alcohol with no bittering and light roast. Mouthfeel is full bodied with almost no carb texture; warming. Overall, just for sipping but not overwhelming enough to stop you from sipping quickly.

draft @ hard liver ¬í09 - dark brown with spotty white head; thick, woody aromas of sugar, molasses, vanilla; thin, strong and silky smooth; not as full bodied as i like, but overall a pretty dope BW that lived up to my excitement when this was spotted on the menu

On tap at Hard Liver Barleywine Festival 09, Brouwer¬ís Cafe. Murky very dark brown with a loose tan head. Doughy, woody nose. Creamy medium body. Wood, vanilla, and doughy malts on the mid-palate. Mild dry finish.

2008 on tap at Brouwer¬ís Hard Liver ¬í09.  Surprise addition to the tap list.  This stuff was great.  Pours dark dark brown with a decent off-white head.  Intense nose of bourbon, oatmeal, and buttery toffee.  Floral hops come through in the taste with a little bit of tobacco as well.  Full mouthfeel, nice bourbon/oatmeal component on the finish.

On tap at the SF Barleywine fest at Toronado. Deep brown pour with a small white head. Very sweet for a barleywine, full of vanilla and a bunch of hop goodness as well. Nice molasses as well and some oaky goodness. Extremely tasty and so damn smooth!
Draught at Toronado. Lots of bourbon in this. Rich and full of vanilla and complete flavors. Very enjoyable.

2009 Boulder Strong Ale Festival: Cloudy brown. Lightish texture but smooth. Rich malts had brown sugar and chocolate. Pleasant aromas, mainly vanilla and dark fruit. Tasty, but lacked some complexity.

Draught at Boulder Strong Ale Festival.  Pours dark brown with a small, fizzy, off-white head, somewhat lasting with fair lacing.  Aroma is heavy malt (nutty, caramel, bread), average hops (flowers, grass), average yeast (dough) with notes of dates, vanilla, wood, and alcohol.  Full bodied, sticky texture, lively carbonation, and an astringent finish.  Average duration, moderate sweetness, light acidity and bitterness.

Draught, Boulder Strong Ale Festival.  Ruby colored beer.  Nose lacks depth, but shows some malt and barrel elements of caramel, toast, toffee.  Upon tasting, not a lot from the original beer.  Sweet, fruity, barrel accented, but not complex or concentrated.  One of the weaker examples of barrel aged strong ale at the fest.

Superbly sticky and cloying candied bourbon consuming the nose, no softness or complexity at all.  Sweet plum juice and wine dominate up front. Rich and overly-sticky charred plum/cheap port across the middle.  Depressingly coarse and flimsy body.  12% alcohol does not guarantee a full body, that comes from the mash...
Crushed with Jakebra at BSAF.  Very nice.  Bourbon complements nicely.  Hops, balance, bourbon, nice.  Dig it.

UPDATED: MAR 12, 2009 On tap at BSAF.  Poured  a deep garnet color with ruby highlights and a thin off-white head that receded to a ring.  Aroma of sweet caramel, some dark fruit (plum, grape, fig), a soft yeastiness, and some moderate spicy bourbon.  Smooth, sweet entry with strong hints of caramel, a bit of toffee, and some spicy bourbon and undertones of plum and fig that finishes moderately dry with some vanilla, oak, and a bit of alcohol.  Low carbonation and smooth on the palate, although a tad thin.  Overall a pretty solid beer, but pretty straight forward and not a lot of nuance.

On tap at Boulder Strong Ale Fest poured a clear dark reddish brown with a small lingering tan head. Aromas of oak, plum, vanilla, toffee, light bourbon and light spice. Palate was medium bodied and smooth with a warming finish. Flavors of bourbon, oak, vanilla, plum, toffee and light carmel with a smooth warming lingering bittersweet finish.
Pours attractive deep brown with some red highlights. Big, sweet toffee, caramel and vanilla nose and flavor. Smooth mouthfeel.

UPDATED: MAR 3, 2012 Sampled at Toronado 2009 Barleywine Festival.
This is the second beer I¬íve had at this event that has simply floored me with its silky rich yummy goodness. Pours deep amber to near dark brown and micro thin tan head. Wow! Toronado Barleywine Fest.  Pours dark brown, bourbon, wood, vanilla, malty, caramel.
Really dark, almost port like beer, strong bourbon, caramel, toffee, oak, chocolate and raisin.  Really warm, rich, medium mouthfeel, slightly slick, with more dry but slightly hot finish.

Draft. Almost black beer with a low off-white head. Bourbon, malt, vanilla aroma. Bourbon, light chocolate, vanilla, malt flavor. Medium bodied with a nice smooth mouthfeel. Lingering caramel, vanilla, bourbon. Alcohol well hidden.
On tap at Churchills.  Big off-white foamy head. A little musty oaky aroma.  I smell a little bit of yeasty auotlysis.  Nice legs on glass.  Sweetish.  You can tast the alcohol.

Draught at The Red in Santa Cruz.   Dark brown with some red, and a small head with no lace.   Rich, malty, salty, and woody aroma with plenty of alcohol. UPDATED: MAR 17, 2014 Rerate 3/17/14: On tap at Beercraft in Rohnert Park. Dark copper with a thin tan head. Deep pudding and coconut aroma. If I liked coconut at all this would be outta sight. Original rating 3/6/08: On tap at The Red in Santa Cruz.

10 oz pour into a small tulip pint glass. Deep auburn in color, with a certain coppery shimmer that only high alcohol beers have. Minimal head with no lacing.

Smell is very strong and sweet, sort of like a less extreme Utopias. Whiskey is the main note, maybe with some dark fruits.

The flavor here is really similar to scotch but with less alcohol bite. Peaty and oaky, with lots of sweet malt and booze-soaked fruit.

Mouthfeel is too low on carbonation but the viscosity is spot-on for a big bad barleywine and the finish is shockingly dry on the tongue.
Herb, vanilla, toffee, fruit and oak nose. Somewhat hot and peppery with dark fruits and candy on the palate. Bourbon is very evident but within boundaries. Nice and somewhat quaffable.

Draft from Toronado Barley Wine Festival. Claims two barrels used at 2 and 1 year, bourbon and wheat whisky. ABV listed as 13. Darker colored. Vanilla oaky body with caramel, various fruit notes, chocolate, sugar. Alcohol hidden well. Solid.

Sampled at the FOBAB.  Perhaps it is because this was the first drink of the day but I found this to be an astringent and hot alcohol mess and it seemed a bit watery to boot.  The Bourbon masked almost all of the barley wine qualities and the bitter hops were all that made it through.  No thanks.

FoBAB 06: Dirty brown hue with sunset highlights and a lasting frothy head. The aroma has notes of old hops, tobacco, smoky and earthy malts, plum, phenolic, and more towards the British styled Barley wines. The taste starts with a smooth toasty malt forefront supported by grassy and peppery hops, olde skool oxidation, and a hint of alcohol. The finish is kinda sweet and sugary but not interfering. The mouth feel is dry, woody, and a tad chalky. Very nice overall, more towards style, I dug it enough to use 2 tickets on it.

#920On Tap at the Goose Island Wriglyville Festival of Wood and Barrel Aged Beers November 4th, 2006. Clear amber rose with a big tan frothy head that is shortly lasting. Nose is sweet, sugary with lots of vanilla. Taste is strong alcohol and creamy sugars and vanilla. Overall very good and strong for a barlywine.

FoBAB 2006. My third favorite barleywine of the day behind Behemouth and GI Brandywine. A bit thinner and less complex than the others, but still solid. Notes of honey and grapefruit on the nose lead into brown sugar and dates. Strong bourbon finish that was a tad on the hot side.

GABF 2006: Clear brown color with a small tan head.  Bourbon aroma hits you first, bordering too much.  Some vanilla notes then you get hints of a fruity malt.  The flavor was big on the bourbon as well.  Fairly sweet with the malt just coming through.  The flavor wasn¬ít as fruity.  Very warming but not peppery.
